Journal Story: Another day of heat and humidity.Â  Trail was much like yesterday.Â  Fitzgerald Falls were a disappointing low flow.

Planning and preparation is nearly done.Â  Have made a few changes from last year.Â  One big change is the flip flop.Â  I admire those hikers who restart back in Georgia.Â  Okay, I've now hiked Ga 3x and just can't face it again so soon!Â  Hahaha.Â  So will start where I left off a section hike last July (near Hampton Tennessee). That way if I make it to Maine but abandon the "flop", I will have section hiked the entire trail.

InÂ  preparation for this year's hike, I made some gear changes.
Â With great angst I retired my favorite, a huge, well used Golite backpack, and switched to a lighter, smaller (but not too small) Gossamer Gear Mariposa.Â  I tried it out on a thruhike of the Foothills Trail last fall and it worked well.Â Â Also discovered that I needed to go back to a full length sleeping pad (at least in colder weather) rather than using a torso length pad with the pack to support my legs.Â  In part because I switched to a down sleeping bag after years of using synthetic bags.Â  No fooling that the top keeps you warm but boy it flattens out underneath you. Another reason to go with a full length pad with decent R value.
So overall base weight is about 22# (that is, not including food and water.) Not too bad but not great.Â  Hahaha - My downfall is throwing in last minute items that aren't on my carefully constructed spreadsheet.

Spring is well underway here in NE Fl.Â  Â Azaleas are in full bloom as are other early flowering plants.Â  Mosquitoes are out in full force too!Â  Won't mind dropping back to late winter weather for a while, though I would mind another polar vortex.Â  Especially looking forward to seeing the spring wildflowers - missed last year during the first covid shutdown.Â  One week to go!

Glad to be back on the trail this year. The trail today to laurel falls was very scenic.Â  Can't beat rocks, a gorge, roaring waterfall and a trail that skirts a lovely creek for several miles.Â  Started off cold at 25 degrees but warmed pleasantly to low 40s.Â  Will be the same tonight.

cold last night in the 20s but bundled up and stayed warm.Â  Slept with water filter, fuel canister and electronics so nothing froze (albeit awkward rolling over with all that stuff in a mummy sleeping bag.) Lovely hike today both weather and scenery.Â  Only the "beach" area at Lake Watauga was disappointingly bleak and eroded.Â  Dam itself was very impressive (trail crossed the dam on the access road.)Â  Stealth camping tonite. Expect freeze again.Â  Great view of Lake and mountains.

Great weather and scenery again today . One advantage of hiking early is that there are no leaves to block the view.Â  Thanks to guthook app I was able to find the campsite and spring. Woohoo!Â  With paper maps I often was not able to tell where I was and thus miss water refill opportunties.Â  Stopped at Vandeventer shelter for lunch. Met Feral who is training for the CDT later this year. Best wishes!

Sunny and warm weather plus a great trail made for easy hiking. Hazy views in morning.Â  After crossing road Tenn 91 the trail went through a working farm. .5m was graded to be wheelchair accessible.Â  Bench provided fabulous views and a place to stretch my aching knees.Â  From there an easy hike to campsite and spring.

Partly cloudy and warmer.Â  Hazy views. A few steeper climbs today but not bad. Water sources a bit scarce so carried a full liter. It's hard to drink enough when the water is really cold!Â  Passes remains of McQueen fire tower - only the cement footings are left.Â  Arrived at shelter about 2:15.Â  Note: so farÂ  all are respecting the "closed facility" notices and are tenting, not using the shelters. Water was a good spring .2m down a steep side trail.Â  Took a nap after that!Â  Later 3 other hikers arrived and tented.

After 5 days of beautiful weather rain was forecasted for today by 9 am.Â  On trail by 6:30 am.Â  Soon passed by Quicksand (previous 2x AT thru hiker.) Later met Commander (previous 1x thru hiker) and young man on a day hike.Â  Joshua and Rowey (long section hikers) caught up and passed me at the Tennessee/ Virginia state line.Â  Light rain, no views and moderate grades made for a quick hike to Damascus.Â  Staying at the Broken Fiddle hostel for 2 nights.Â  Those longer, easier days still wore me out a bit!Â  Btw just updated entries with photos for this week.

Took a zero day today in Damascus.Â  Ate a huge breakfast at a local diner, resupplied at Dollar General and rested.Â  More hikers and other guests at the hostel tonight.Â  Nice chat with "Woo girl" who completed her AT thru hike last summer (started about 10 days before me and so made it through the Smokies before they closed.) Feeling refreshed and ready to resume hiking.

mt rogers outfitters provided a shuttle north to fox creek va 603 trail crossing.Â  Morning was chilly but clear, later cloudy.Â  Even though I section hiked this area several years ago, it looks very different this time of year!Â  Rain forecasted by evening and early tomorrow so did not stop at the Scales (too windy and e xposed) but went on to the tenting area just north of Wise shelter and creek.)Â  Bear box seemed further away than it really was.. Love the bear boxes!Â  Plan for a short hike tomorrow after the rain quits.

Lots of rocks and views.Â  No ponies until lunch break when a small group arrived, following some other hikers.Â  Ponies were begging and were not to be deterred, so I had to move to another location fo finish lunch and drying off my tents rain fly. Set up tent in Grove of spruce/fir within view of bear box.Â  Somewhat sheltered from strong winds but decided to skip cooking dinner and go with another lunch.

Very foggy start.Â  Wet rain fly again, although stayed dry inside tent. Cold again in part to strong wind that didn't let up.Â  Â Quick hiking south. Saw 2 deer after hearing their warning snort. Met Wild Card and dog Ace who are nobo. Later Quicksand passed by.Â  Beautiful views before Elk Garden.Â  Also pleasantly surprised by open views from Buzzard Knob. Day hikers visiting from OK were there when I arrived.Â  Later saw a ruffled grouse run ahead on the trail before taking flight. Have heard their distant drumming occasionally this week.

Beginning to see thru hikers on a regular basis.Â  Spoke to Reset who started in early January and Not Today who started in late Jan.Â  That's a lot of cold weather!Â  Biscuit and dog Roo had just left the Lost Mt shelter.Â  Ice bear and Sonar were ahead of them. The highlights of the day was the Virginia Creeper Trail and the lovel Whitton Laurel Creek.Â  Biking the Virginia Creeper Trail is definitely on my bucket list! In the afternoon the AT began a long, steady climb (the reward being a phone signal).Â  After a ridge with small loose rocks hidden by oak leaves (very annoying), arrived at Saunders Shelter.Â  Very nice, set under white pines, with a picnic table and flat areas for tenting.Â  Heavy rain started about 8 pm (as forecasted) and lasted most of the night.

Morning hike was in scattered drizzle with a hard rain about mid day.Â  Hard to enjoy the views when eye glasses stay fogged!Â  Trail did parallel the Virginia Creeper Trail and the Whitetop Laurel Creek again today - lovely! The last 4 miles were nice but unremarkable, paying attention to ground so didn't slip.Â  Very tired by the time I reached town as I didn't take the usual rest breaks due to the weather.Â  Taking a zero tomorrow as rain is predicted for part of Friday too.

Took a shuttleÂ  from Damascus to the Fox Creek vs 603 crossing, this time headed north. Lots of cars in the parking lot - a good day for day hiking Grayson Highlands!Â Â 
Good hiking and nice woods heading north.Â  Â Crossed seven streams during the afternoon.Â  Detour due to bridge washout still in place.Â  Stealth camped along trail that evening.Â  Hurricane NFS campground not open yet for the season.
Destination: Trail detour due to bridge washout

Journal Story:
Detour roadwalk of 1.5 miles this am.Â  Surprisingly pleasant as no traffic. Signs posted announced trout stocked streams. Road was twisty and rather steep up to Dickys Gap.Â  Â 
Again, very pleasant woods during the day (Racoon Branch Wilderness).Â  Chilly wind on knob and ridge, warmer below.Â  Was beginning to argue with myself to add some miles today - that is until I stopped at Trimpi shelter and saw how nice this area is for camping.

Shortly after leaving the shelter the trail passed through pastures touched with overnight frost.Â  A deer gave itself away on the next mountain. A steep climb transitioned to a wonderfully flat, graded trail for awhile (old rail line?) View cleared on ridge for "Rey Valley". Can see how in summer Virginia is called the long green tunnel, but now views can be seen through the many trees. Rhododendrons formed a tunnel the last mile or so.Â  No flower buds yet.Â  Partnership shelter is very nice. Nearby is the Mt Rogers headquarters. Tented nearby. Photo of Reset, Paul, Biscuit, Ice Bear and Roo (under the table).

A rather chilly, grey day.Â  Â More blowouts on trail from earlier storms.Â  Few views today.Â  Reached Chatfield shelter by 1 pm, too early to stop.Â  Felt okay so continued on to Rural Retreat and the Relax Inn where I have a mail drop and hope to get a room. Btw, not counting naturalized daffodils and forsythia, finally saw patches of spring beauties in flower.

Before hitting the trail, grabbed a large coffee and some donuts to start the day.Â  Weather forecast not looking good for Thursday.Â  Trail followed the road a bit (underpass for I81).Â  Then crossed meadows and pastures (some required climbing over V- shaped stiles).Â  Area was settled in mid 1700s according to historical markers.Â  Afternoon saw a series of short but steep climbs.Â  Sun came out so was hot! Of course pack was heavy after resupply yesterday.Â  Haven't mastered the art of resupply yet. Great campsite by Reed Creek.Â  It was right next to the trail so I could say hello to those coming through - Butter, Not Today, Reset and Laf (Paul).Â  Btw lots of downed branches and trees on trail today from earlier storms. Barred Owls heard at night.Â  Saw another pair of deer in the morning.

As expected, Reed Creek campsite was a bit damp and chilly in the morning.Â  Rain expected by late morning so on trail early.Â  Some steep ups and downs like yesterday but much of today's short hike was through scenic meadows and pastures. The area around the North Fork of the Holston River was lovely.Â  Hepaticas were blooming by the path down to the river.Â  Â Stiles grew larger and a bit harder to climb over!Â  Reached VA 42 and Bear Garden Hostel (a short walk) before the rain started. Later other hikers arrived - nice to see both new and familiar faces.

Eager to get hiking while weather is good. Several steep climbs in the morning.Â  Multiple streams later in day.Â  Knew that the Lick Creek foot bridge was out and could be nearly waist deep.Â  Even with rain the day before, was onlyÂ  about knee deep and not bad at all. Tevis water sandals worked great!Â  The 2nd stream was only about ankle deep but dutifully took boots off to keep them dry inside. After leaving the Lick Creek area, the long climb to Chestnut Knob was a steady grade, not too steep, for about 4 miles. Last climb was a fabulous open vista on a mowed grassy trail.Â  No water at shelter but had gotten enough earlier for overnight.Â  After a short stint through woods again, came out to the open Chestnut Knob.Â  The shelter is enclosed with some bunks and picnic tables.Â  I tented outside with a great view of Burkes Garden below.Â  Very windy.

The day started off lovely - clear and not too cold.Â  Rain and thunderstorms forecasted for later in the day and next day.Â  Intrigued by Burkes Garden and preferring to avoid 2 days of rain, decided to visit the hostel in Burkes Garden.Â  Website, guthook and landline answering machine - none indicated that the hostel was no longer. Worse, the 2 miles from trail turned out to be "as the crow flies".Â  Later, Google maps showed it to be 5.1 miles each way.Â  So to make a long story short, ended up stealth camping near the hostel/retreat (no one there but clearly being renovated), met a lovely German Shepherd who was so glad to see someone and stayed close by all night (what an angel!), stayed dry in tent as 3 rounds of major thunderstorms passed over at night (had to sit up and help brace the tent against strong winds each time.) Boots didn't stay dry, though, when tent vestible blew in during the night. Oh well. Ironically I'm low on water. But I'm not drinking out of that boot- hahaha.
Sigh, my fault for not speaking with a live human first...

Break in the rain about 5 am, so packed up and started the walk back to the trail at 6:30 am (still dark so used headlamp until got light enough.) Rain started again about 8 am but no thunderstorms. Walk back not too bad now that I knew what to expect.
Btw this is part of Virginia scenic highway.Â  Horse and buggy caution signs for motorists (Amish or other sect?) Interestingly each of the two intersections had white painted signs with the names of the residents and the distances to each farm/home.Â  As this was before dawn on a Sunday, only saw a few farmers up and lots of cows in pastures.Â 
Back on trail by 9:30 am.Â  Trying not to think about the 10 extra miles for naught but cows.Â  Trail was wet and slippery. Passed by 9 southbound section hikers.Â  Luckily they called out a greeting each time as I couldn't see well with wet/fogged glasses and a rain hood riding low.Â  Was tired by that time and, sure enough, slipped on a wet rock and landed like an upside-down turtle on my pack. Not hurt but the adrenaline rush drains you once it wears off.Â  Stayed overnight at Jenkins Shelter.Â  Multiple hikers arrived over time.Â  Another excellent dog, Alice, a Siberia husky, section hiking with Todd, helped lift my spirits and kept the mice away in the shelter.Â  Damp and cold overnight. I was warm and dry in designated dry clothes and sleeping bag.Â  Hahaha- dread putting on wet and cold hiking clothes in the morning!

Getting packed and putting on wet/cold clothes for hiking was tough.Â  Compromised with myself and only changed into wet socks and long pants over dry nike running capris. Fleece hoody is still very wet.Â  Bubble jacket is dry and I have gloves and a wool cap to wear until I warm up.Â  
Very pleasant hiking. All nobo hikers pass me sooner than later, as expected. Some are trying to make it to Brushy Mtn. Outpost (grill & short-term resupply)before they close at 2 pm(still limited hours.)Â  Decided to take my time, so stopped midday to dry out tent and some clothes (found a sunny, dry spot next to the trail with a fallen tree to sit on.)Â  Just loved the hike on Brushy Mountain - pine and oak woods, steep drop offs, and great views this time of year. Turkey vultures glided by at eye level, just beyond the trees.Â 
About 3 miles before hwy 52 I finally decided that I needed a good rest before fatigue and bad weather gets me.Â  So called the Weary Feet Hostel and arranged for a shuttle pick up at 5 pm that day.Â  Will rest there Tuesday (even though great weather!), Wed (rain all day) and part or all of Thursday (cold snap may be too low for my sleeping bag.)Â 
Weary Feet is a great Hostel! Highly recommend it. Big Rig, CVS and Owl have taken a couple of days off here and leave on Tuesday. I'll be here to at leastÂ  Thursday.Â  Will return to trail at hwy 52 then, hiking about 4 days to Pearisburg and next mail drop.

Can't believe that today is the last day of March!Â  Glad I am keeping a journal so I can remember places, names and adventures/misadventures. Hikers here included Big Rig, CVS, Owl (left yesterday); Rev, Dryker, Random (hiking together, slack packing today in rain), The Onion (car hiking/yellow blazing; left today); Aspinock, Pippin, Biscuit & dog Roo, Stephanie.
Great breakfasts and dinners here! Feeling better after eating real food and less sugar/candy.

Woo hoo! Snow flurries today (not sticking, whew) What a treat to see for this Floridian! Wind chill is a factor today also.
Last night the hostel was quite full with hikers due to the rain and forecasted cold weather.Â  Most hikers (that is, everyone but me) headed back to the trail today.Â  I am antsy to resume hiking but the forecasted low of 19 degrees tonight are colder than my sleeping gear can handle comfortably.Â  So stretching and resting one more day, then back on trail tomorrow.

After breakfast, shuttled back to hwy 52. Air temperature of 24 degrees. Wind chill though was lower. Amazing to see dusting of snow and ice at higher elevations. Frost crunchy beneath feet. Very nice hike. Some views of farms below between trees.Â  Tenting at Jenny Knob Shelter.Â  Several thru hikers arrived- Wiggle Wag, Zooming and Halo. It was still very cold at night!

Very cold last night. Stayed mostly comfortable wearing almost all clothing,.Â  That is, 2 pairs of wool socks, Nike running capris, Patagonia mid wt. long underwear, wool tee shirt, Patagonia long sleeve mid wt base layer shirt, fleece hoodie, bubble jacket with hood, wool cap (plus the 2 jacket hoods.)Â  Did not need gloves in the sleeping bag.Â Â 
Trail was a bit rougher than yesterday. The wind blew all day. By Kimberling Creek the first wildflowers were budding. A bit ragged from the storm, though.Â  Skipped the sidetrail to Dismal Falls.Â  Trail followed Dismal creek for quite a ways. Sometimes Trail was very muddy, making for slow going.Â  Camping at Walnut Flats near to a small stream.

Gun shots last night at 2 am echoed eerily in the mountains.Â  Have no idea what that was about.Â 
Weather is warmer. Hiking trail mostly okay. Saw a few other hikers.Â  Was undecided about where to stop for the night.Â  Finally decided to push through to Doc Knob Shelter (a bit leery of stealth camping given the gun shots the prior night ).Â  Should add that the ice storms last February really did a number on this area.Â  Tons of blow downs. Tops of younger trees broken off. The trail was mostly clear due to the herculean efforts of the Roanoke club. Thank you!
Enjoyed a solitary night at Doctor Knob Shelter. No tenting due to rocks. Great deck and sitting area for hikers!
.

No one else at the Doc Knob shelter last night. Love the deck and seating set up!Â  No mice that I saw.Â  Â Expected to be tired after yesterday's long (for me) mileage and I was.Â  Nice hiking in spots. More blow downs awaiting trail maintenance so that also slowed me down. Hahaha until a man came jogging by with his Siberian Husky (wearing a bell.) Then I realized I'm just going slow. Some nice views from the ridge of farms below.Â  Did not climb up Angel Rest rock formation for a view.Â  Save it for next time. At lower elevations I was side tracked by swaths of early wildflowers.Â  In full boom were: Blood root, cutleafed toothwort, dutchmans breeches, hepatica, spring beauties and woodland phlox (blue) Not counting chickweed and Speedwell. Earlier saw patches of yellow colts foot.Â  A new flower for me is the Blue eyed Mary.Â  It is growing in large patches at lower elevations. Need to get a photo next time!
Staying in bunk house at Angel's Rest hostel.Â  Another great hostel.Â  Heated bathrooms! Wicked, Viking man, Not Yet, Tallson, and Tenacious are also here in the bunkhouse. Others are tenting or have private rooms. Btw - have I mentioned how much I love grocery stores?Â  A Food Lion is around the corner.Â  Picked up resupply box at post office before they closed at 4:30. Took it with me and stopped to get some juice and yogurt on the way back.

Taking the day off from hiking.Â  Did laundry and showered last night.Â  So replanning and relaxing today.Â  And another trip to Food Lion.Â  Won't lose weight at this rate but slowly getting my "trail legs".Â 
Â The next section of trail is closed while repairs are made - the Feb. ice storms tore up 6 transmission towers on Peters Mtn.Â  Will get a shuttle ($10) around the closure on Wednesday (and revisit in the fall.)

Shuttle took 3 of us to the parking area near mile 657.Â  Started off nicely following a lovely creek.Â  Soon after crossing the road the trail began a lengthy climb, then several miles of rocks pretending to be a trail. Nothing to recommend except that eventually the trail left the rocks and made its way through nice, open woods. Crossed mountain lake road, a fabulous overlook of mountains, and camped on a lovely Grassy spot. No cell signal though.

Laurel Creek shelter was a welcome sight after a rather tiring day.Â  Did I mention that a made a rookie mistake of oversupply and now my pack is just too darn heavy. The next wave of through hikers is passing, over 13 by 5 pm.Â  No one else in the shelter tonight.

What a great stretch of trail!Â  The trail was pleasant, not rocky,Â  not too steep. Foggy and damp morning.Â  Afternoon partly cloudy with chance of storms.Â  After passing the sidetrack to the next shelter, the ridge line was mostly large, slanted rocks, requiring someÂ  climbing and caution.Â  Made it to the end of the ridge just before a storm came through.Â  Niday shelter was empty. 3 other hikers came later and tented.Â  Hail storm at 2 am.

On trail by 7:00 am.Â  Nice easy trail to road crossing. Got to pet a lovely Golden Retriever (Chief) while chatting with his owner.Â  Trail then ascended over the next 2+ miles.Â  Good grade, cool and foggy made for great hiking. Ate lunch at the Audie Murphy memorial.Â  Spring flowers abound now, need to look some of these up when I get to town.Â  Serviceberry shrubs are in full bloom in the understory (white).Â  The small Deerberry shrubs are covered in bloom too.Â  Arrived at shelter ahead of the forecasted rain.Â  Other hikers arrived and the shelter filled up. Hard, steady rain started just after 5 pm and continued most of the night.

I hiked the "triple crown" 6 or so years ago so basically knew what to expect.Â  Haha - it's amazing what your memory edits out!Â  A long, hard climb to Dragons Tooth, with some great views near the top.Â  Very rocky.Â  Lots of day hikers coming up from the other direction. Skipped the side trail to the "tooth" as I'd seen it before.Â  Trail going down was rather tricky due to steepness and some water still draining from the rain. Took pack off twice to err on side of caution in a couple of spots (pack holding up well so far to some manhandling.) Impressed at the trail improvements (more erosion control, better white blaze markings).Â  Â Camped by lovely creek about .1 mile from parking lot.Â  A bit close to Dragons Tooth trail, though, so day hikers could be heard clearly.

Started off early to dump trash in bear proof container at Dragons Tooth trail parking lot.Â  Frees up both space and weight in backpack.Â  Vaguely remembered most of today's trail.Â  Legs are feeling a bit beat up from yesterday So moving slowly. Amazing how spring is suddenly everywhere. Greening is creeping higher everyday up the mountain sides.Â  Won't be long before the views are gone!Â Â 
Parking area for McAfees Knob is nearly full. Glad I won't be there until tomorrow to miss the crowd.Â  Took long Beak at John's Spring shelter.Â  Quick hike to official campsite just north of Catawba Shelter.Â  5 other tenters arrived by 6 pm.

McAfee Knob and Tinker Cliffs are the final highlights of the "triple crown".Â  Arrived at McAfee Knob after the dawn watchers left and before the day hikers arrived. Very peaceful to have the fabulous views to oneself.Â  Had forgotten that it's about 6 miles further to Tinker Cliffs.Â  Love the views but the heights make my knees weak.Â  Arrived at Lambert Meadow campsite (next to a creek). Glad to see a bear box and picnic table there. A young doe was grazing on new grass.Â  She stayed awhile and even circled back.Â  Set up my tent and took a nap.Â  Other hikers arrived later.Â  This is the last camping spot allowed before Daleville.

Eager to get to town and beat the rain forecasted for noon. On trail at 6:30 am, just able to the trail clearly.Â  First 4-5 miles was fast, easy hiking.Â  Then up and down over rocky knobs.Â  In touch with husband Tom by text on when and where to meet up in Daleville. Did have to stop and take a photo of a large black rat snake half out of a hole in a tree.Â  Not moving.Â  Perhaps hoping not to be seen?Â  Something one doesn't see everyday, for sure.Â 
Â Lush spring greenery around Tinker Creek. Development is very close to the trail here.Â  Staying at the Super 8 and will resupply at nearby Grocery store and outfitter (msr fuel.)
Trying to avoid over resupply from grocery store. Sending some winter clothes back home.Â  Meanwhile enjoying "real food" and using phone with decent wifiÂ  ( vs no wifi on trail.)

After waiting for a long freight train to pass, started on the trail at us 11, the Troutville trailhead at 7:40 am. Cool temperature in the am.Â  Lovely wildflowers.Â  Hmm, the pasture with cows several years ago no longer has cows. Will it be overgrown in a few years?Â  Rest of day went pretty quickly. Vivid purple Gaywings are blooming!Â  Tenting at Wilson Creek shelter with other hikers.

Trail ascended after leaving Wilson Creek Shelter until the Blue Ridge Parkway.Â  Â Rest of the day the trail ran parallel to or crossed the BRP.Â  Great views although partly cloudy.Â  Excellent variety of wildflowers in bloom.Â  Red Columbine was fabulous.Â  Didn't stop at Bobblets Shelter this time.Â  Went another couple of miles to Bearwallow Gap, VA 43 and stealth camped (water available in creek.)Â  Could hear traffic on road so not perfect spot for tenting.Â  Woken the next morning by a Whipporwill and Barred Owl calling before dawn.Â  What a great alarm clock!

Excellent trail today.Â  Vaguely recalled hiking here several years ago; burned over areas have grown up considerably . Pink azalea blooming (only one spotted so far.) Took a long lunch break at Jennings Creek.Â  Fork Mountain wasn't too much fun, though.Â  Finally made it to Bryant Ridge Shelter.Â  Very impressive!Â  Only 3 of us there (Sundance and Midnight) and rain forecasted so we spread out and set our tents up inside.Â  Btw, there are no good tenting spots here.Â  A large broken limb hung high above endangers the only two tenting possibilities.Â  Also, I felt bad that in moving a chunk of oak, I disturbed a mouse and its nest.Â  Thank goodness no babies in the nest. What would I have done then?!

Very nice hiking but some long climbs.Â  Some lovely displays of wildflowers made up for it.Â  Violets gave way to white blood root blooms on Floyd Mtn.Â  A green ribbon of grass along the trail is enticing.Â  A whole hillside was covered in blooming dutchmans breeches.Â  A couple of blooming trillium bodes well for seeing more over the next few days.Â  Apple Orchard Mtn took forever to hike over.Â  Radar station at top was a surprise. Crossed the BRP again to get to the Shelter.Â  Love bear boxes but this one was really hard to open and shut. Tented on grass.

A couple of hard climbs today but mostly smooth hiking. Rather hot afternoon with little shade.Â  Great views of James River before descending.Â  Pink azaleas in bloom.Â  Trilliums in bloom. Many wood phlox in bloom too. A long day for this hiker.Â  Tented next to Matt's Creek near the shelter.Â  Too tired to cook dinner.Â  Rested and read kindle books until falling asleep.Â  Hung bear bag in dark!
Short hike today to James River Foot Bridge.Â  Yesterday arranged shuttle pickup for 9:30 am.Â  (As expected no phone service once off the ridge.)Â  Taking a rest day today and resupply at hostel.

To avoid carrying 7 days worth of food, decided to break this section into a mini flip flop.Â  That is, took a shuttle to Salt Log Gap ($40) and now hiking south to the James River Bridge and Glasgow.Â  Will call for a shuttle pick up Sunday morning.Â Â 
Today was very windy with icy wind chill at Salt Log Gap. Tar Jacket Ridge had wonderful views but too cold to enjoy! Prescribed burns done recently are helping to keep the balds open (mowing, too.) Didn't stop at Hog Pen Gap shelter (.6 mile off trail).Â  Took a short break at the US 60 hwy wayside where I had a phone signal!Â  Remaining section followed a fabulous creek, Brown Mountain Creek.Â  Remnants of fireplaces and stone walls from before 1920s are visible.Â  Excellent tenting next to creek near shelter. Half of the hikers from the hostel were there! They hiked over 20 miles, while I hiked a mere 10.9 miles. Fun to see familiar faces.]]

A bit chilly this morning - rather hard to get moving out of a warm sleeping bag!Â  Next 5 or so miles south continued along the lovely creek.Â  Lots of wildflowers!Â  A lovely yellow lady's slipper orchid took my breath away and made my whole day.Â  Dwarf crested irises were blooming in large patches.Â  Took more flower photos than planned.Â  I suppose it's good that the trail went higher and left the rich lowlands, or I'dÂ  never get the days hike done. Spied the Lynchburg reservoir and dam through the trees.Â  Reached the Punchbowl Mtn Shelter rather early but too tired to go on.Â  A group of section hikers is here too.Â  Rain forecasted for tomorrow Saturday.
.

Rain forecasted for this afternoon (100%) so headed for the next shelter at first light.Â  Rather steep ascent to Punchbowl mtn summit then Bluff Mtn but great views at top. Old fire tower cement footings at Bluff Mtn summit.Â  Â Mostly downhill after that.Â  Great views of James River below from Big and Little Rocky Rows (cliff ledges).Â  A few thru hikers heading north trying to beat the rain also.Â  Reached John's Hollow Shelter by 1 pm, well ahead of rain.Â  Joined later by a couple of section hikers and a thru hiker.Â  Good to rest legs and feet which are complaining after all the down hills.

Oops, no photo today.Â  Did see first red eft of the hike on the trail.Â  A bit chilly and damp from the rains.Â  Stayed dry in the shelter but dampness permeates everything.Â  Lovely (short) hike back to the James River Foot Bridge where I met my shuttle back to Glasgow.
Note: It's light enough now to start hiking by 6:15 am if I could get going early enough.Â  Starting about 6:30 am regularly now.

After a breakfast of French toast and coffee, the hostel hikers again scattered to the winds via the hostel shuttle drivers.Â  Some are slackpacking (leaving their full pack at the hostel and returning that night.)Â  Others were continuing their hike from the James River Foot Bridge.Â  I was the outlier, shuttled back to Salt Log Gap and continuing my hike north.Â  Unfortunately I was fighting a migraine from overnight so wasn't feeling 100%.Â  Decided to camp early and rest.Â  Tenting tonight at Porters Gap which has a lot of flat tent sites and a spring.Â  Saw 3 deer when I first arrived. More hikers today than I expected- several southbound section hikers and a small group of thru hikers who were slackpacking a bit, then going to the Priest shelter.Â  Â Btw no good photo today...

After a short day yesterday, seemed like a longer hike was called for. I was rested up, right?Â  Well it did turn out to be a long day for me.Â  Started off at 6:30 am.Â  Did take the sidetrail to the highly recommended Spy Rock - very impressive 360 views; very windy so didn't linger.Â  Made good time to the Priest Shelter where I took a long lunch break.Â  Dreaded the long, 4 mile descent, so took it slow with lots of breaks.Â  Grade wasn't too bad, just long.Â  Started to get hot which didn't help.Â  Finally made it to the highway and Tye River crossing (another suspension bridge) by late afternoon.Â  The trail to Harpers Creek was about 3 miles, mostly uphill, pretty nice except for having to stop every 15 minutes, before continuing. Carried enough water, just hot in the late day sun.Â  Shelter is in a lovely spot with the creek running nearby.Â  Arrived around 6 pm. Chatted with the few other hikers there before crashing early.

On trail early to try and beat the heat.Â  As expected the hike up to Three Ridges Mountain was beautiful but strenuous.Â  There are great views along the way from various cliffs and ledges.Â  Flat grassy areas at summit look great for camping if you bring your own water.Â  Hanging Rock Overlook provided great views back to the Priest and Three Ridges Mountain.Â  In the low 80s by the time I made it to Maupin Field Shelter area.Â  Took a short day as water and tenting spots look to be limited ahead and further than I wanted to hike.

The next shelter is 15.8 miles away and, while mostly downhill, it is too far for me at this point.Â  So will hike to a tenting area just north of Bear Spring.Â  The trail crossed the Blue Ridge Parkway a couple of times.Â  Refilled water at Dripping Rock overlook on the Blue Ridge Parkway.Â  A nearby resort comes close to the trail here and houses can be seen through the woods.Â  Appreciate that this sight is unusual outside of trail towns.
Â Humpback Mountain was the main event of the day.Â  Not a huge climb but the rock "steps" to divert water/erosion were a bit too high at times.Â  Hard to get upward momentum when tired!Â Â 
Piped spring was about .2 mile before the flat tenting area.Â  Several deer came at dusk, browsing until dark. Light rain shower at night. Wind dried tent off by morning.
Destination: Tenting area near Bear Spring mile 855.5

Journal Story: Up early, eager to get to town.Â  Lovely, fast hiking.Â  Mix of uphill and downhill.Â  Stopped briefly at the Paul C. Wolfe shelterÂ  - nice creek runs by it.Â  Strong breeze turned into gale force wind at Rockfish Gap!Â  Sheltered behind informational signs at the parkway parking lot to call for ride to hostel.Â  Amazed to see a bicyclist (in colorful latex and helmet) pedal up to the Parkway and keep going - what a tailwind!Â  Planning to take a zero tomorrow (Saturday) and possibly Sunday.Â  Knees and lower legs feel good (thanks to compression socks and cho -pat knee braces) but hips and upper thighs are feeling rather weak and tired.
Start location: Tenting area near Bear Spring mile 855.5

Journal Story: Happy belated May day everyone!Â  Taking two zero hiking days here.Â  Having a very comfortable place to stay plus convenient resupply and dining made the decision easy.Â  I should say "easier" as it's hard not to get antsy when the morning shuttle takes off to deliver hikers to the trail.Spending these 2 days resupplying, then regretting the weight of that resupply. Going through my pack and food to really try to winnow out what I don't really need. Boy, is that harder than it sounds!Â  Â The "Waste not, want not" mindset is really engrained and argues constantly with the light weight backpacking philosophy.The contrast was highlighted this morning when a hiker was putting several single serving electrolyte/energy packets into the hiker box.Â  The weight saving was neglible. In contrast, after not finding these packets in one town, I stocked up here with enough for several weeks (plus trying out some other brands). It's gonna be hot, right?Â  And I'll need to keep hydrated, right? Too bad I used up the pink lemonade packets that I wasn't too fond of - those I could donate to the hiker box!

Took the earliest shuttle back to Rockfish Gap. Know you've had enough zero days when you're eager to hike in the rain!Â  Â Trail was nothing too strenuous or rocky.Â  Early rain gave way to dense fog. No views today. One rabbit seen.Â  Shrubs looking like Dwarf dogwoods were in full bloom. Missed getting a photo. Thunderstorms were forecasted so arrived at shelter as soon as possible.Â  Later, shelter filled with other hikers looking to avoid the storms.Â  Some rain overnight but no thunderstorms.

On trail early to beat the heat. It was a long day that got quite hot in the sun.Â  One long stretch of about 12 miles without water, except for the trail angels who left water and drinks just past one road crossing.Â  Later met other trail angels from Augusta, Georgia who had drinks and snacks for hikers. Thank you Toe Smoke and Master Toddy!Â  A pop up thunderstorm chased me the remaining mile to the shelter.Â  Rain mostly passed by.Â  Shelter filled with other hikers looking to avoid the rain. Tenters also.Â  No rain overnight. No photo for today although the pink azaleas were outstanding!

Up early and out of crowded shelter at first light.Â  Trail continues to be in good condition.Â  Did not stop at Loft Mountain campground store as I still had plenty of food and wanted to keep the momentum going. Woods here look very beat up from past storms.Â  Mother nature is not always attractive! Arrived early at Pinefield Hut and tented in one of the designated tent spots.Â  Bummer - Kindle display died (old and well used.) Didn't cook dinner, instead ate tuna in tortillas.Â  Photo is of the cement sign posts used in this park at all intersections.Â  Very helpful as metal band has direction and mileage. I stop and read these regularly.

Sometimes the days just don't turn out the way you expect.. Plan was to hike at least as far as the Hightop Hut.Â  Well, the air was crisp and cool, trail conditions were great, and I arrived at the Hightop Hut by 11 am.Â  Cooked a dinner and took a long lunch break (1 hr.) and decided to go a bit further. Next shelter was too far, though.Â  Figured I'd go as far as the next good stealth camping spot.Â  To make a long story short, ended up hiking 15 miles total.Â  Restricted camping near some park areas and lack of water didn't help.Â  Also woods are either too rocky or too many downed trees and branches.Â  Finally found a flat spot next to a fire road that fit the bill, just before dark.Â  Trilliums in bloom covered acres and acres of mountainsides today.
Destination: Stealth camp South Fork Fire Road

Journal Story: Rain forecasted for early morning so on trail by 7 am.Â  Only 4 miles to the Lewis Mountain Campground.Â  Was able to get a camping spot as this section was first come first serve.Â  Rain started as I put my tent up and continued most of the day.Â  Was able to recharge my phone and powerbank outside the campsite. Also bought some food resupply there.Â  Rain ended around nightfall.
Start location: Stealth camp South Fork Fire Road

Journal Story:
Bizarrely, car campers pulled into my camping spot late last night.Â  Guess my not having a car confused them?
Anyway, on trail by 7 am. Quite chilly last night with temperatures in the mid 30s. Again, good hiking but I was still feeling tired and a bit achy.Â  Didn't go to the wayside for resupply as it was uphill .3 miles.Â  Did go to the Big Meadows Lodge restaurant for lunch.Â  Delicious!Â  Plus they let me bring my backpack and poles inside.Â  Food coma from hamburger and cheesecake ðŸ˜‹.Â  Â Lots of day hikers.Â  Rockspring Hut has nice tent pads.Â  Water supply does indeed spring from a boulder downhill of the shelter.

Very chilly last night, in the mid 30s.Â  On trail early.Â  Trail is very rocky in places.Â  Rained lightly for about 45 minutes.Â  Some views of the valley despite clouds. Haggis, a section hiker, passed by, she's going to eat breakfas at Skyland.Â  There is still a lengthy, outrageous detour at Skyland due to construction. Some hikers not taking it.Â  I started to take it until I lost sight of the markers and a blast of cold wind hit me in the face.Â  Now quite aggravated, I cut over on a shorter connecting road and met up with the trail again. Did not take the side trail to Stoney Man Mountain. Popular with day hikers so maybe worth returning to one day.Â  Later cooked dinner at the Pinnacles Picnic area that the trail passes through.Â  Picnic tables, bathrooms and water! Nice except for the wind.Â  Reenergized but legs still feeling tired.Â  Stopped for the day at Bryds Nest Shelter.Â  Weather forecast kept changing regarding rain chances.Â  Finally set up tent nearby, expecting no rain and for the wind to abate. Instead the wind continued to blow strongly until the early hours.Â  While warm and comfortable in tent, could not sleep for fear of falling tree limbs (everytime a tree creaked) or fixing the tent fly when stakes blew out (vestibule gave way a couple of times.) Still, it was warmer than the Hut which directly faced the wind.

I should mention that I always try to have a "plan B" whenever possible.Â  Plan A was to hike 12+ miles to Elkwallow wayside to resupply and recharge phone, and stealth camp location TBD.Â  Waking up with the birds, after only a few hours of sleep, led me to reconsider my plans for the day after hiking a bit.Â  Mental fortitude is as important as physical and I definitely needed a rest.
So Plan B was to contact the Open Arms hostel and see if a bed and a shuttle ride were available at such short notice. I called from Mary's Rock overlook/view about 7:30 am and was fortunate to catch the shuttle about 8:30 am.Â  Thank you, Alison! Will spend today and a zero tomorrow here at the Open Arms hostel.No photo today.

Taking a zero today.Â  Alison drove us hikers to Walmart yesterday afternoon for resupply while she ran errands (definitely not in walking distance). Hahaha, I've resupplied for 6 days, rather than the 3 days to Front Royal, my next town stop.Â  That's only about 6 extra pounds of food to carry.Â  Yah would've thought I'd learned by now...There's that saying (paraphrased): " I don't make a mistake just once, I make it several times just to be sure!"

Shuttle dropped me off at Thornton Gap at 8:19 am.Â  Pleasant hiking but nothing remarkable.Â  Pack a bit heavy and legs a bit tired, so took frequent rest stops and a longer lunch break. Weather cleared by late afternoon.Â  Very nice stealth camping spot near Piney Ridge Trail.Â  Joined later by Happy Feet and Coffee Bean who started their flip flop at Rockfish Gap.

Another first - in the middle of the night, zipped a deer mouse in the tent, then couldn't get it to leave!Â 
Â That is, after waking up about midnight, I left the tent unzipped for a few minutes while I went outside (cool, no bugs).Â  Returned to tent after finishing my business, zipped up tent and sleeping bag.Â  Heard a buzzing noise, turned on headlamp several times to see what bug flew in.Â  However the scampering across my sleeping bad was definitely not a bug.Â  Sure enough in the corner of my one person tent is a deer mouse.Â  I was probably blinding it with my headlamp and there isn't much extra room in the tent, so even with the door unzipped the mouse could not find the exit! We went around and around for a bit before I heaved my pack out the door, then Mr. Mouse took a giant leap after it and disappeared into the night.Â  Whew!
Apologized for the noise to Coffee Bean and Happy Feet later that day- did I see a bear? No, zipped a mouse into my tent while I was in it.
After a good hike, stealth camped just beyond Compton Springs.Â  Deer seen in the area.Â  Large cleared spot for several tents was mouse-free.

Fast hike today, mostly downhill.Â  Several deer crossed the trail.Â  Didn't stop at the Tom Floyd shelter.Â  No Name caught up with me, she's going to the new Stumble Inn hostel. They graciously dropped me off at the Super 8 in Front Royal, after my husband was delayed several hours due to the gas shortages in NC.

Zero day at Super 8 motel.Â  Resupplied at Martin's grocery and outfitter downtown (needed 2 replacements for lost stakes.) No guest laundry here, though.)Â  Ate at a hipster burger place yesterday and local diner today - yum.Â  Made reservation for Quality Inn in Harpers Ferry in five days. Back on trail tomorrow morning.Â  Expect a glut of hikers returning from trail days in Damascus.

Tom dropped me off at 6 am (he had a long drive back to Florida).Â  Parking lot at us 522 was almost full!Â  Enjoyable hike to Jim and Molly Dentom shelter.Â  Wish I had planned to stay there - very deluxe! Very busy location with weekend hikers.Â  More hills and steeper on the afternoon. Light rain started at 12:45 . Arrived at Manassas Gap shelter by 1:15.Â  Put up tent quickly. Not too wet but damp and chilly. The few hikers at the shelter were heading out once the rain stopped but I'm done for the day. Saw 1 rabbit and 1 deer today.

Very good trail for most of the day.Â  Saw a couple of new wild flowers to look up.Â  Trilliums fading fast.Â  Mid day passed through Sky Meadows State Park. Trails and distances well marked.Â  Â Meadows provided some expansive views. Recently mowed trail grasses smelled wonderful! Did not stop at Whiskey Gap shelter.Â  Trail crosses US 50, a somewhat busy 4 lane highway.Â  A grass divider between each direction made it doable.Â  Trail maintainers had just cleared the downed trees north of the highway so easier going.

On the trail early but couldn't beat the heat.Â  Lots of cool down rest stops today.Â  Knee high compression socks are very warm so won't be able to keep wearing them much longer. Entered the "roller coaster" section of the trail.Â  So lots of fairly steep ups and downs.Â  Very pleasant woods.Â  Occasionally very fragrant!Â  Saw a small fringe tree in full bloom.Â  Arrived at Bears Den Hostel about 3 pm.Â  Recharged devices and set up tent outside while waiting for the camp store to open at 5 pm.Â  Hoping for some ice cream.

This section of the trail is very pleasant hiking.Â  Pink azaleas and white fringe trees are in bloom.Â  Great stay at Bears Den Hostel last night.Â  Rather anticlimactic end to the "roller coaster" after a long climb.Â  Afternoons are getting hot so slowed down and took frequent cool down breaks.Â  The David Lesser Memorial shelter had a very challenging hike to water, both steep and long.Â  Tenting area had been hard hit by downed trees/storm damage although campsites had been cleared.Â  Wondered about the number of circular holes in the ground.Â  Stakes? Hiking poles?Â  Answer: cicadas.Â  More emerged at night, crawling up the tent screens.Â  Not noisy yet!

Lovely weather - warm but low humidity. Some breeze.Â  Fast hike first 4 miles or so.Â  Then rocks appeared!Â  The ankle twisting kind.Â  Small sign announced the Va - West VA state line. Yesterday the trail meandered across the state line multiple times. This is it, though; finished the AT in Virginia!Â  Trail descended steeply through Harper Ferry National Historical Park until it went under US 340 hwy,Â  next to the Shenandoah River. Then, up a set of stairs to the pedestrian walkway (next to US 340) and across the Shenandoah River.Â  Quality Inn is about .1 m from the trail.Â  Picked up resupply box from Post Office.Â  Afternoon is quite hot!Â  This is actually the historic town of Bolivar; tomorrow will pass through Harpers Ferry.

Felt like I need a zero day but decided to take advantage of good weather and press onwards.Â  After a late start of 7:30 am, took my time walking to enjoy the cooler air and historical sights. Stopped briefly at Jefferson Rock (can cross that one off the bucket list!).Â  Enjoyed the C&O tow path, imaging what it must have looked like in its heyday. Today it's shaded by trees and perfumed by wild roses and honeysuckle.Â  After several miles,Â  was ready for the trail to climb back up the mountain.Â  Weverton Cliffs provided the best view of the Potomac River below.Â  Arrived early afternoon at the shelter.Â  Good tenting spots. A long, steep hike down to an excellent spring.Â  Other hikers, including several families, arrived later.Â  Didn't cool off much at night.Â  No cicadas on tent!

A long, warm day but interesting.Â  Arrived early at Gathland State Park.Â  Potable water, flush toilet, civil war historical markers and the war correspondents memorial makes this a hidden gem.Â  Later, lots of weekend/day hikers and trail runners.Â  Â Had to encourage a black rat snake to leave the trail (lots of day hikers had dogs).Â  Joy! A pink lady's slipper orchid blooming demurely by the trail! Almost missed it.Â  Dahlgren Backpacker Campground provided flush toilets, potable water, hot showers, some picnic tables and room to pack in a LOT of tents.Â  A mix of weekend groups with kids, section hikers and thru hikers, all getting along.

Two miles after getting on the trail, arrived at Washington Monument State Park.Â  That is, the original one built in 1827.Â  Campground sounded full, as I passed by but no one at the monument yet.Â  Climbed the spiral staircase up the rather squat stone tower, greeted by 360 views of the valley below and surrounding mountains.Â  Took a long lunch break at Pine Knob Shelter and filled up on water (scarce on ridges. ) Earlier crossed I70 on a footbridge. Lots of families and day hikers going to Annapolis Rock and also to Black Rock Cliff.Â  Stopped at Black Rock Cliff overlook later in the day.Â  Pretty much same view, only slightly different perspective.Â  Campsite was a surprise (not a good one). Obviously crews had been working to build a new privy.Â  Campsites plentiful but not many were flat.Â  Luckily Guthook comments had good description of where to find water, so I settled down, fairly close to the trail.Â  Eventually a couple if other hikers arrived.Â  Light rain for a couple of hours just before dawn.

Today was rather a blur, as rainy days often are. And not just because my glasses stay fogged up!Â  Phone doesn't like the moisture so didn't think about taking photos much.Â  Â Much cooler than yesterday. Stopped briefly at Ensign Cowell shelter for a break. Rain stopped for a few hours.Â  Ignored the Raven Rock pile as passed by, trying to beat the rain.Â  Rain had just resumed when I neared the shelter and quickly pitched the tent in a very nice flat, well drained tenting spot.Â  Luckily had a good signal so could see the weather radar and heavy rains coming.Â  By dusk could emerge from the tent without getting soaked.Â  The shelter was very nice, pretty full at that point. Had arranged for shuttle pickup the next morning at Pen Mar road, so less concerned about tent drying out (which it didn't.) Glad I had dry clothes to change into earlier, a warm sleeping bag and fleece and bubble jackets.Â  I was chilled enough that it was several hours before I warmed up enough to feel good. Read books on kindle and was content.

Foggy, cool morning.Â  No views. Everything still damp.Â  Good, fast trail to start.Â  High Rock overlook attracted a few day hikers even with the weather.Â  Â Trail was very rocky from there down to Pen Mar County Park.Â  The county park is another gem, with flush toilets, potable water, and historical markers.Â  Â Small sign marked the Mason Dixon line and entry into Pennsylvania.Â  Met shuttle driver at Pen Mar Road and now settled in at the Days Inn on West Main Street in Waynesboro.Â  Will take a zero hiking day tomorrow and back on trail Thursday.

Enjoyed a quiet zero day in Waynesboro, Pennsylvania.Â  Revisited the Dollar General store for a few resupply items.Â  Also a quick visit to the convenience store a few blocks away.Â  Enjoy seeing the old houses and buildings along West Main street.Â  Hot and humid summer- like weather.Â  Will stretch and relax the rest of the day indoors as thunderstorms are forecasted.Â  Tomorrow is looking like a great day for hiking!

Dropped off by shuttle driver about 7:30 am.Â  Temperature is not cool enough to wear my fleece hoodie and humidity from rain makes it feel even warmer.Â  Nice hiking through open, green woods.Â  In some spots mountain laurel is starting to bloom.Â  Cicadas are numerous in some places, like scattered rain clouds.Â  None to be seen in other spots, some times just yards away.Â  Great trail magic today at Iron Forge Picnic area, including hotdogs, soda, chips and honey buns/cup cakes.Â  Thank you, Tycoon!Â  Big Talker and Mose were there also.Â  Short day ended at Tumbling Run Shelters (kudos to caretaker/club for how nice this area is maintained.) Have set up my tent in a designated tenting area and will snooze awhile.

On trail by 5:40 am (first light).Â  Overall, trail was fast today. No rocky surprises or steep climbs.Â  Caledonia State Park looked very nice in passing.Â  Trail went right by restrooms, bear proof trash container and potable water, of which, of course, I took advantage.Â  Woo hoo! First chipmunks of the year seen here!Â  After a steep climb out of the park, the trail wasn't bad at all.Â  Arrived at Quarry Gap shelter well ahead of the forecasted rain. Loved the flowers and little decorative touches at the shelter.Â  Nicest so far.Â  As forecasted the heavy rains did arrive and continued through the night.Â  Shelter filled up and tenters arrived also.Â  Covered picnic tables made the rain a bit more bearable.

The weather forecast kept changing for today.Â  When rain stopped about 7 am, I was on the trail, intending to get to the next shelter, Birch Run, before heavier rain started about 1 pm.Â  One never knows what the trail will be like, so I was pleased to have another section of fast trail with only a few rocky spots.Â  The weather was damp and drizzly, though, so even, or because, I was wearing rain gear, I arrived quite damp. Partially unpacked, ate and took a nap but never could get warm.Â  After 2 hours, nap over, heavier rain had not arrived and passing hikers heard that it would stay drizzly.Â  Decided to head to next shelter after all, only 6.5 miles.Â  Arrived by 5 pm, heavy drizzle and trees dripping kept me quite damp.Â  Not bad weather to hike in but not to stop and take rest breaks. Shared the small shelter with the hikers from the night before and another thru hiker.Â  Sleeping bag was decidedly damp and feathers were clumping more than usually.Â  This meant more cold spots, where the bag couldn't hold my body heat. Hmmm...

Well, I intended to hike to the next shelter.Â  Morning temperature was 44 degrees at the shelter and still drizzling.Â  Felt fine hiking but was dreading another chilly, damp night.Â  Stopped at the Pine Grove Furnace General Store for some breakfast and coffee.Â  Started to get very chilled.Â  Chatted with a fellow from a nearby cabin (he had a lovely English Springer spaniel with him) and he recommended this hostel.Â  For some reason I hadn't considered it before but quickly changed my mind.Â  Now warm, dry and devices recharging, all is right again.Â  Only downside was that both the general store and hostel are cash only.Â  There is an ATM in the General Store if needed. (I'd rather pay an additional fee to use credit card.) BTW,Â  I was very pleased to see Pennsylvania actively managing this state forest - kudos!

On trail by 6 am. Trail passes directly in front of the hostel and turns just before the Appalachian Trail Museum (will have to visit another time).Â  Easy hiking, first through the state park, then over low ridges. Other hikers from the hostel passed me early in the day.Â  About 11 am reached the Green Mountain General Store and joined three other hikers at one on the picnic tables out front. It is an easy walk from the trail on busy hwy 34.Â  After getting some lunch and resupply for a couple of days, headed back to the trail.Â  By early afternoon, reached my planned campsite.Â  It felt too early to stop but my legs were feeling tired.Â  I've gotten a bit faster and stronger but still don't have the stamina to hike all day.Â  Yes. OK. I still carry too much food.

Not a long hike today.Â  Today started out with playful trail blazes going up and over large boulders, or squeezing through narrow rock passageways. The additional white arrows were very helpful.Â  Stopped briefly at the next shelter for a break.Â  Two more chipmunks spotted.Â  Later in the day, a medium size black rat snake was seen crossing the trail.Â  After the shelter, the next water source was in the town of Boiling Springs.Â  Decided to stay at the backpackers' campsite, just outside of town.Â  First visited town. Pleasantly surprised to see lovely, spring fed lake as the "old" town's centerpiece, with park benches, lots of shade and ducks.Â  The AT office there was still closed due to covid.Â  Water from faucet around back.Â  Picked up some snacks and drinks from the nearby convenience store.Â  Later on in the park, trail magic in the form of cold sodas was offered to hikers - thank you!Â  So after eating a pint of ice cream and a cold zero coke, felt much better.Â  Sugar, fats and caffeine - woo hoo!

As expected, several trains passed by last night.Â  Was awake when the last one went by about 4:30 am. Hiking by 5:40 am.Â  Trail followed a narrow corridor for most of the day.Â  Mostly overgrown woods fragrant with rampant honeysuckle and wild roses.Â  Poison ivy, too!Â  Â At times, the trail skirted or crossed, farm fields. Wildlife seen included 5 deer, 2 rabbits, 1 large, grouchy raccoon, and a dinner plate sized snapping turtle. Expecting rain later tonight and all day Thursday so will be staying at the Quality Inn, a short walk from the trail, on US 11 in Carlisle. Car show in town this weekend so rooms for Thursday are scarce and pricey.

After a zero day at the hotel on June 3rd, was ready to resume hiking.Â  Cloudy and wet but not raining when left hotel just after 7:08 am.Â  Crossed large open fields in the morning and later in the afternoon.Â  Would've been brutal if not for the cloud cover and slightly lower temperature. Trail is mostly flat and fast. Traveled across extensive boardwalk over wetlands next to large creek. Daylights are budding but not yet blooming.Â  Â Afternoon meadows had a variety of purple flowered legumes, ox eye daisies, blue eyed grass, yellow coreopsis, and white baby's breath.Â  Trail magic was almost gone but did snag a Jarlsberg cheese stick and a Golden Triple Monkey ale. Cove Mountain Shelter had porcupine warnings posted but none appeared. ( Protective aluminum flashings around Shelter and privy were clawed and/or chewed.)

Early start due to forecasted heat in 90s. Left at 5:37 am. Took a spill almost immediately (not paying attention while thinking about upcoming day.) Unhurt except for a small bump on side of head and a scraped palm.Â  Very lucky; a reminder to slow down and pay attention.Â  Hawk Rock view of the Juniata and Susquehanna rivers was great.Â  Chatted with a local hiker who caught the sunrise.Â  Onward to town of Duncannon, Pennsylvania.Â  First hiked to local grocery store (kind of on the way, added 1.2 miles not in total above.)Â  Then walked to Post Offiice to pick up small resupply box.Â  Returned to Kind of Outdoorsy outfitter/hostel to check it out & recharge phone.Â  After a long break there, chatting with other hikers, resumed hike on trail through town.Â  Crossing the 2 river bridges on the hot afternoon sun, next to heavy traffic, was rather arduous.Â  At least no trains in sight while crossing 3 sets of tracks before reaching the steep climb up the mountain.Â  Later tore hole in the seat of my pants on a unforgiving rock.Â  Last couple of miles were hot and rocky, insult upon injury it seemed at the time.Â  Took a while to recover at the shelter picnic table.Â  But good conversation with the other hikers over a wide range of topics while eating dinner and rehydrating, was refreshing and invigorating.Â  (Clementine, 100 Percent, MC Yogi and others.)

Hottest day yet (90s).A long hike.Â  Trail was flat and fast. Water scarce. Took a 2 hour break at Peters Mtn Shelter at halfway point for the day.Â  Water was a steep .2 m down and up. Very exhausting.Â  Took it very slow the rest of the day. Only 1 day hiker in afternoon.Â  Decent campsite bear spring so decided to stop there rather than to the large creek and camping area next to the road.
Destination: Mile 1167 Tent site and spring before Clark Valley Rd.

Journal Story: Food bag way too heavy again - really feeling it today. Weather not as hot to start but very humid. Trail was flat and fast, or would be if not so humid.Â  Passed 9 or so southbound section hikers. Fewer northbound thru hikers.Â  Â Rausch shelter area is one of my favorites on the trail so far. Beautiful creek, pine trees and soft campsites, large grassy open area near shelter and spring water.Â  Storm clouds passed by early evening and nice breeze set in. Minimal to no phone signal, though.
Start location: Mile 1167 Tent site and spring before Clark Valley Rd.

Journal Story: Would have loved to stay longer at Rausch Creek.Â  Resembles GSMNP creeks.Â  Shortly crossed the beaver dam with no trouble (only a bit of water overflowing. If there had been a lot of rain, there is a blue blazed alternative around it.) Later in the morning passed through Swarta Gap State Park, previously an old canal (1830s-1860s). Iron Bridge crossed over the large creek. No amenities for hikers except for a garbage can. Long, hot afternoon hike. Trail not bad, just periodic rock fields. Arrived about 4 pm. Tented.Â  Heard thunder but no rain.

Short hiking day today. Did not sleep much last night due to leg cramps.Â  So very tired with tired legs.Â  No one else at 501 shelter that early except for the caretaker.Â  Very nice guy. I rested most of day at picnic table until it got too hot.Â  Later shelter filled up with thru hikers. Arranged to stay at a hostel tomorrow. Badly need shower and laundry.Â  And to fully rehydrate.

Slept well last night.Â  And didn't get lost on trek to Porta potty (a very nice clean one) after dark.Â  Up and on trail by 5:40 am.Â  No breeze and humid so worked up a sweat quickly.Â  Trail is increasingly rocky, although there still are periodic smooth sections.Â  Very few views this section. Arrived at pa 183 by 12:30 pm for shuttle pickup to hostel.Â  Looking forward to getting cleaned up and a quick trip to Dollar General store.

After a delicious breakfast at the hostel, dropped off and on the trail before 8:30 am.Â  Cool temperature and barely a misty rain made for good hiking in the morning.Â  Stopped at the Eagle's Nest shelter for lunch/dinner.Â  (Cooked a mountain house.) Several other hikers also stopped for lunch, as did a couple of section hikers.Â  Rain set in for real by this time and we all were getting chilled.Â  Resumed hiking as I needed to pick up a mail drop from Port Clinton post office by 11 am on Saturday.Â  (Food resupply plus a pair of pants without a hole in the seat!)Â  No fun trudging in the rain.Â  Have to be careful on wet rocks. Rain abated somewhat when I arrived at campsite. Lovely spot on soft ground under living hemlock.Â  Managed to get dry and comfortable in the tent. No photos today.

On trail before 6:15 am.Â  Only 3.1 miles to town.Â  Trail not bad but steep downhill the last mile was difficult for my legs.Â  Still feeling stiff in left leg and hip. Port Clinton is a very small town with some charm.Â  Picked up packages from Post Office by 10 am.Â  Walked over to the pavilion and camping area for AT hikers.Â  Spread out gear and partially set up tent to dry.Â  After about 3 hrs, having dried out, eaten dinner and repacked, used the porta potty, was ready to resume hiking. Actually my head was ready but the legs, not so much. Trail leaving town followed the Schuylkill River for a bit, then climbed steeply back to the ridgeline.Â  Weather had warmed up so frequent cool down stops were needed.Â  Wanted to go to the next shelter but too tired. So stopped at campsite just past Pocahontas Spring.Â  Set up tent and now dealing with leg cramps.Â  Expect rain later tonight and tomorrow.

The trail today wound ( in a large zip zag fashion) through and around the town of Hamburg, Pennsylvania watershed.Â  Nice to see it open for hiking with a loop trail option.Â  There are two very popular overlooks: the Pulpit and the Pinnacle.Â  A large number of day hikers at the Pinnacle mid day. Known for its resident rattlesnakes, there was only one small one sunning on this partly cloudy day.Â Â I was trudging today.Â  Moving okay uphill but my gimpy left leg and hip were tight and not cooperating on downhills.Â  This made for a very long day. Arrived at the Eck shelter about 4:30.Â  One bunk available,Â  thanks to a hiker who opted to tent instead (Thank you Poker Face!).Â  Have a top bunk and managed to get up and down okay.Â  Thunderstorms and rain forecasted for overnight.

Not a bad trail getting started. Became one of the most difficult trails so far. Long stretches of ankle twisting rocks.Â  Need to call this activity something other than hiking. Rock Dancing? Rock Rolling?Â  Have to say that I never want to repeat this section of Pennsylvania again.Â  Shelter is nice but water was a very long walk.Â  Stayed in Shelter when weather forecast changed to severe thunderstorm warning. Several hours of rain (Shelter was full.)

First 4 to 5 miles of trail today was a woods road, very pleasant change from yesterday.Â  Once past t he powerlines, the trail became very rocky. The Knife's Edge section was very challenging, especially when wearing knee braces and carrying hiking poles.Â  Had to butt crawl several times to get over some difficult sections but did not tear my pants!Â  Rest of trail was rocky but not as bad as day before.Â  At the Bake Oven Knob parking lot, several of us decided to order pizza delivery.Â  Only a mile to the shelter, right?Â  Hahaha, turned out to be a rocky mess of a trail, at least when carrying pizza boxes and soda.Â  We finally arrived and the pizza was fabulous!Â  Small, old shelter. No rain forecasted so tenting is preferred.

Surprisingly good trail today especially compared to the last two days. Much of the woods trail was flat and long.Â  I was up early as usual. Other hikers caught up and passed me mid morning. Many hikers going directly into Palmerton, but I have enough food and don't need to resupply. George W. Outerbridge is an old style shelter perched next to the trail.Â  No picnic table or privy (as far as I'm concerned, these are the main attractions of a shelter, outside of rain protection.) Had a nice chat with Smatt, the ridge runner for this section of trail.Â  Especially helpful about trail conditions ahead.Â  Thank you, Smatt!Â  Went down the trail another .3 mile to a campsite with a nearby spring.Â  Was able to dry everything out in the sun - wonderful!Â  (Even if not directly rained on, everything gets damp and will mildew if not dried out soon.) One hammocker set up nearby later in the day.Â Â No photo today.
Destination: Tent site .3 mile past George W. Outerbridge

Journal Story: I was anxious about the notoriously difficult boulder scramble coming out of Palmerton on the AT.Â  Especially with a full pack and knees that don't bend too well. (I don't have enough upper body strength to hold my pack above my head when it's full, so would be in trouble if that is called for.)Â  Instead I took the Winter Trail by-pass.Â  What a joy! No boulders and trail is very well groomed and well graded. Who would have thought that the Palmerton EPA superfund area would be one of my favorite sections of trail.Â  Later in the day water became an issue when heard that Delps Spring was dry. Ended up going further to Smith Gap where the water cache still had some water.Â  Went about .1 mile further and stealth camped.
Start location: Tent site .3 mile past George W. Outerbridge

Journal Story: No rain last night. Awake at 4:45 am and on trail by 6 am. Nice woods but nothing special. Rocks are annoying but few terribly annoying spots.Â  Made it to Wind Gap by noon.Â  Weather getting hot by then. Took it slow and walked to the Cafe on Broadway first.Â  Delicious! Had a small spinach salad, rueben sandwich with chips, milk shake, peach tea, and water. Recharged phone. Shared table with another thru hiker so good conversation. Next stopped at Turkey Hill gas station/mini mart to resupply for 2 days.Â  Also bought another liter water bottle as the water cache at the Gap was empty. Stealth camped about .1 mile north of Wind Gap parking lot.Â  Often hear traffic noise from the trail but hwy 33 was not far away and unexpectedly noisy all night.

Rained last night for several hours. Tent rainfly still wet in morning. On trail by 6:30 am. Took it slow due to wet rocks. Also tired legs definitely need a couple of zero days.Â  Wolf Rock is reputed to be hard but okay when rocks are dry, but more treacherous when rocks are wet.Â  Saw the ridge runner again and got the scoop on the wolf rock bypass trail.Â  Marked only by "spring" and a square rock on the southern intersection with AT.Â  Found it to be clearly blue blazed once the spring sign and large square rock were found. Arrived at Kirkridge shelter by early afternoon. Time enough to dry out tent in readiness for more rain that evening.Â  Two hammockers, a group if 4 weekend hikers and other thru hikers in the shelter/shelter area before rain started.Â  Water was a nice spigot provided by a nearby retreat center.Â  Â Rained overnight but stopped before dawn.

On trail by 6:30 am again.Â  Will have to dry out tent fly. Everything is damp again.Â  Very slow hiking today due to wet, slippery rocks. Beautiful area with some views of the Delaware River and Gap.Â  Views dominated by the interstate and traffic noise. Lots of day hikers, in part because it's Father's Day and a weekend. The small Lake Lenape is lovely with blooming water lilies, lots of frogs and small fish, benches and a picnic table. Arrived at parking lot before noon.Â  Have scheduled an Uber ride to pick me up at 1:45 pm.Â  Staying at the Quality Inn at East Stroudsburg, PA for a couple of zero (rest) days before heading into NJ.
Destination: AT Parking lot at Lakeside Road & Quality Inn

Journal Story: Taking a couple of zero days. Legs just not energized lately.Â  Could be the rocky trail but best to take a couple of days off.
Rainy day. Not a bad one to be in town. Ready to resume hike tomorrow.

Dropped off at AT Parking lot by Uber driver by 7:30 am. Short walk through the edge of town, then across the bridge over the Delaware River. Hahaha - rather unnerving when large semi trucks cause the bridge to shake, especially when there's 2 or 3.Â  New Jersey and Pennsylvania state line is painted on the foot walk, for photo ops between trucks passing.Â  Once across the river, strolled through the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation area (Kittatinny visitor center was nearby.) This section of New Jersey is wild and beautiful (even with noise pollution from the Interstate traffic.)Â  Saw my first Black Bear this hike, shortly after entering Worthington State Forest.Â  Trail skirted Sunfish Pond, a glacial pond. Frankly, it seemed like the glacier dropped all of its rocks on the trail next to the pond!Â  Later, Mt Kittatinny summit was a pleasant surprise with 360 degree views. Very clear views today due to low humidity.Â  Stayed at a walk-in tent site at the AMC Mohican Outdoor Center.Â  Greatly enjoyed chatting with the hikers in the next tent site. Took advantage of the small deli and resupply.Â  Also bought tick repellent and a lightweight poncho (ditched the rain jacket which was too hot to hike in.) Did I mention how numerous ticks are in NJ?Â  Lastly, while I love Whipoorwills,Â  they made it difficult to sleep that night.Â  Reminded me of the song Dueling Banjos, that is, two Whipoorwills singing louder and faster at each other, then starting all over again. This started about 9 pm right next to the tenting area.
Start location: AT Parking lot at Lakeside Road & Quality Inn

Journal Story:
A long day of hiking but necessary to get to the next bear box!Â  Up early and on trail by 6:30 am.Â  Great views to the south from rock ledges.Â 
Woo Hoo ! About 10 am almost walked into a porcupine on the trail(a narrow, rather overgrown section, its head was in the bushes, maybe it thought it was hidden?) Unfortunately I wasn't fast enough to get a photo before it ambled off down the mountain.Â Â 
Later passed a lovely beaver pond with 2 lodges and flowering water lilies. Didn't get a good look atÂ  Crater lake.Â  Blueberries are ripening!Â 
Alot of hikers going to Brink shelter today.Â  Saw some familiar faces (Anikan, Oscar the dog, No Name, Packman) and met new hikers catching up and passing me (White Walker, Wubah and others)Â  Ridge Runner, Skirt, came over at dinner to chat with a group of us.
First time this hike that I've had to pull off ticks.Â  Even found a couple in my tent.Â  Gives me the heeby jeebies!

Short hike planned for today. Spacing of shelters with water and bear boxes is a key consideration.Â  Also tired from yesterday's hike.Â 
Nice hike into Culver's Gap..Stopped at Sandwich Lobby for 2 breakfast sandwiches (egg and bacon), juice, coffee, and snacks for next 2 days.Â  Oh, and 2 sodas (mountain dew). Recharged my phone which took awhile.Â  Resulting food coma convinced me to stop for the day at Gren Anderson shelter, as planned.Â  So resting up, checking for ticks (yikes, another one!), update trail journal, now going to take a nap.

Overall nice hiking.Â  Nothing too strenuous.Â  Low on food so planned to stop at the High Point State Park headquarters (snacks and soda) then on to the concession stand at the lake-side beach.Â  Trail passed by an observation deck with great views of the stone obelisk marking New Jersey's highest Point.Â  Chance of showers passed with only a brief, light misting. Got some impromtude instruction from " Lost and Found" on how to get rides into town without hitchhiking per se (in case shuttles and uber don't work out ). Had hotdogs, ice cream and more soda while charging phone, etc under the roof of the bath house/concessions.Â  Passed on taking a shower as I faced an immediate hot and sweaty climb back to the trail and then to the shelter. Only a few hikers at the High Point Shelter.Â  Most thru hikers are doing 15 -20 mile days so the wave moved on quickly.

NJ has some of the most pleasant hiking on the trail.Â  After leaving High Point state park, the trail criss-crossed over old stone fences where farmers had laboriously cleared rocks from fields and pastures, now returned to woods.Â  Active hay fields were recently mown and drying then baling were underway. Regular road crossings too.Â  Headed into Unionville, NY for resupply and lunch at Horler's General Store. Outstanding roast beef sub, ice cream, and a liter of mountain dew.Â  Hahaha, I could easily give up water and just carry soda! Afternoon took us around and through the Wallkill National Wildlife Refuge for migratory birds.Â  Too bad the sun was searing by then so couldn't linger. Lots of "board walks" across swampy ground today. Glad not to have to slog through mud!Â  Only a couple of us at the shelter area tonight.Â  Very warm, even after sunset.

Weather got quite hot as the day progressed.Â  Put a damper on the highlight of the day - the Pochuck Creek boardwalk.Â  Usually "boardwalk" on the trail means 1 to 3 boards laying on top of some sort of low base (logs or other boards, commonly.)Â  Now this was a real boardwalk, winding over a mile across a lovely swamp and creek but frying today in the sun midday.Â  Later stopped at the Heaven Hill Farm and Deli for some food.Â  Geared towards tourists, did purchased some drinks, apple cider donuts, and a discounted loaf of French bread.Â  Oh, and their ice cream.Â  Charged phone at the charging station aka rickety outlet on side of building until shade disappeared.Â  Chatted there with a section hiker whom I first met back in Maryland who had returned to section hike NJ.Â  Great to see a familiar face!

Woo hoo!Â  Exited NJ and crossed into NY. Trail has changed, becoming a bit more challenging with more rocky boulder climbs.Â  Forecasted heat and humidity made me cautious.Â  Water sources a bit scarce on this section, due to lack of rain.Â  So when arrived at Furnace Creek, decided to chill out by a good water source.Â  Good stealth camp sites nearby convinced me to rest the rest of the day.

Another day of the heat wave.Â  Trail much like yesterday, overall good but exposed rock ledges and short, steep Boulder climbs more challenging in the heat.Â  Got water at Wildcat shelter spring but decided to go a bit further as it was still late morning.Â  Fitzgerald Falls were a disappointing low flow. Creek feeding the Falls still had nice pools. A pair of cedar wax wings protested when I refilled water at one nice pool. Heard baby birds cheeping near by. Nice!Â  Ended up not-so-stealthily tenting not far up the trail.Â  Severe thunderstorms in area, had to go with a spot not too close to dead trees (hemlock and green ash trees, in particular) and not covered in poison ivy.

After deciding yesterday to go into town for a day or two, felt under pressure to get to the scheduled pick up spot on time.Â  8 miles by 12:30 pm was doable depending upon weather and trail conditions.Â  Turned out to be much the same with regular rocky boulder climbs and steep descents. Started light rain about 11:00 am.Â  Got pretty wet, especially when butt crawling down one or two slippery boulders.Â  Arrived just at 12:30; taxi delayed a bit.Â  Trail angel was there so had a nice conversation, a large Gatorade and snack while waiting.Â  Once at the hotel and after showering,Â  took Uber to town for resupply.Â  Will stay on Friday also as rain is forecasted all day.
Destination: NY 17 Arden Valley Rd to Monroe NY

Journal Story: Taking a needed rest day. Very nice hotel but not within walking distance of town.Â  Fortunately Uber has drivers here and I was able to run errands and resupply without a problem.Â  Village Taxi picked me up from NY 17 Arden ValleyÂ  Road trailhead and will drop me off there tomorrow.
Destination: Sleep Inn and Suites, Monroe, NY

Journal Story:
Took the Village Taxi back to the trail.Â  Misty and light rain all morning and late afternoon. Much cooler, in the mid 60s. The lightweight poncho worked well. Also gave the gaiters a second chance. They did a pretty good job keeping my pant legs from getting soaked and muddy.Â  Overall, ended up throughly damp but not wringing wet. Think that's the best one can hope for.
Hike today was in Harriman State Park. Very lovely green, open woods.Â  Clouds concealed the lake.Â  Early on went through the so called lemon squeeze, a tight rock formation, easily without my pack on. The vertical climb that followed was too wet and difficult for me, so took the short side trail around it.Â  No other tough spots but was careful on all rocks to avoid slipping.Â 
The old, stone shelter was just off the trail. Rather unique in that a huge boulder was used as the back side of the shelter (damp as water seeped down.) Stayed in shelter because of expected evening shower.Â  Sparks and Skittles, two hikers I had met earlier in Pennsylvania were already there. Great to see familiar faces Glad!Â  Glad that the resident rattlesnake was a no show that night! (I still dreamt of snakes.)Â  Treehouse came before dark but decided to tent.Â  Another hiker arrived around midnight!
No photo today.
Start location: NY 17 Arden Valley Rd to Monroe NY

Journal Story: Happy 4th of July!Â  Great hiking weather. Cool in morning, no rain.Â  Getting the hang of NY terrain: some rocky climbs, rock ledges and easy hiking stretches in between.Â  Some great trail magic today before Bear Mountain ascent - a 2019 thru hiker Crush with his wife and baby daughter, had a grill set up and were serving egg sandwiches and pancakes along with water and sodas to passing thru hikers.Â  Thank you!Â  Now energized, enjoyed the trek up Bear Mountain.Â  As expected, the holiday and good weather had tourists and day hikers out in droves at the summit.Â  I was surprised by how many were hiking up the other side, though, as I was descending. It was steep, even with the manicured trail, and quite warm!Â  The lakeside area was full of picnicking groups and families.
