Got a Powerade and Coke from a vending machine, then headed for the Hudson River crossing.Â  It was 4 pm so missed the Trailside Bear Mountain Zoo - took the bypass trail instead.Â  Crossed the highway, read historic markers for Fort Clinton and Fort Montgomery- both saw action during the Revolutionary War!Â  A huge American Flag hung above the bridge.Â  A nice walk across the bridge. Heavy traffic and some other walkers, but no huge trucks.Â  On the opposite side, many cars were parked on the road shoulder so had to dodge on coming traffic for a bit until the trail connectedÂ  to the woods again.. The steep climb was over quickly (Bear Mt really wore me out after all!).Â  No one else at Hemlock Springs campsite. At dusk, asÂ  I was tieing my ursack bear bag, two bears passed nearby!Â  Yikes!Â  Firework booms were loud and continued for a couple of hours.

Foggy and damp - hard to get going this morning!Â  Took it easy and careful on trail.Â  No views in the morning.Â  Stopped at Appalachian Deli and Market about 11:30 am - it's right on hwy 52 next to the trail.Â  Took a long break while charging phone.Â  Bought soda, juice, fresh fruit, a hero sandwich, and bug spray (mosquitoes!).Â  Weather cleared in afternoon and got warmer.Â  Took "cool down" breaks. As it got later, decided to stop where there was good water.Â  This stealth spot was near a good brook and relatively flat.Â  Tons of mosquitoes as expected near water.No photo today.

On trail by 6:30 am.Â  Weather fine to start, but quickly heated up.Â  Trail goes through Fahnestock State Park so different regulations on where one can camp.Â  Derrytown Road parking area was grassy and had trash bins and water but no camping.Â  Later the trail followed old mining roads built into the rocky mountainside.Â  Lake Canopus is beautiful.Â  Went down to the park concessions and decided to stay the night.Â  I'm just not handling the heat and humidity well.Â  Btw - No fee for thru hikers to tent in a designated field.Â  Bathrooms (locked at night) and water a short walk away.
Severe thunderstorms came through as forecasted. Stayed dry in tent.Â  Other hikers arrived after the worst of the storms.

Packed up wringing wet tent rain fly and damp/wet tent and footprint.Â  Seven other tents on the field.Â  Left early to beat the heat. Refilled water bottles at drinking fountains. (Bathrooms locked overnight). .5 mile route from tenting field back to trail went quickly.Â  Trail continued through pleasant woods, nothing too strenuous except for the heat.Â  Carrying extra water due to warnings over the next 20 miles.Â  Rain from tropical storm Elsa forecasted for next couple of days. Almost out of food so resupply needed, too. Took a lunch break on Hosner Mountain and made arrangements for hotel stay in Fishkill, NY.Â  Also spread the tent rain fly out to dry. Finally stopped looking at my phone and spotted a dramatic caterpillar waving threateningly at my feet; almost ready to turn into a butterfly.Â  Later passed by the fixed up RPH cement block shelter.Â  Very nice plantings, too!Â  Â Very hazy, cloudy skies may result in evening thunderstorms. So decided to arrange an uber ride to town that day, instead a suffering through rain again overnight.Â  Took about a half hour for a driver to become available. Not complaining as the trail seemed to be out in the middle of nowhere!

Tropical storm Elsa is forecasted to move up the coast and through this area late Thursday and early Friday.Â Â 
Twisted left knee overnight so a bit swollen and gimpy today.Â  Did laundry and then took an uber to Shop Rite grocery store.Â  Scattered storms today.Â  Flash flood warnings for this area.
Steady rain for first half of day.Â  Revising plan for Connecticut.Â  Not seeing many affordable places to stay near the trail. Grocery/resupply options look good, though.

Uber ride at 8 am to AT Parking lot on NY hwy 52.Â  On trail before 8:30 am. Nice trail and hiking weather.Â  Some hazy views of green mountains. Passed Nuclear Lake in the afternoon, a few swimmers taking advantage of the good weather.Â  Numerous side trails are part of Pawling Nature Preserve.Â  Telephone Pioneers Shelter side trail crossed a roaring stream.Â  Tented on hill behind shelter near other tenters. No bear box.Â  Woke at night to sound of large animal running past the tent.Â  Didn't sleep well after that!

Really enjoyed hiking NY. River Swamp has a boardwalk crossing the river and thickets of cattails. Many muddy sections of trail today. Fun seeing the railroad stop on the AT and I would have loved to stop at the Native Plants Nursery (it was too early on a Sunday morning.) Passed Wiley Shelter, the last NY shelter but didn't stay.Â Â 
Even though Guthook shows the detour route, I failed to comprehend that a footbridge on the trail was out and to NOT follow the white blazes.Â  So had to backtrack a bit in the afternoon.Â  Road walk took me about 45 minutes.Â  Painfully slow as knee was bothering me at that point.Â  No new blazes to follow so kept guthook open as the guide.Â  At last made it to Connecticut!Â  Btw, several trail magic spots made a huge difference in today's hike (drinks and a snack). Felt so much better!Â  Forecasted rain held off until just after I reached the Ten Mile River shelter and set up my tent.Â  Legs really hurting and need to stretch and rest.

Overnight rain continued into the morning.Â  Packed up very wet tent during a brief lull a b out 7 am.Â  Housatonic River is raging from all of the rain.Â  Missed a great photo asÂ  the phone acts up when it gets wet.Rain let up during the afternoon but no views to speak of from Schaghticoke Mountain.Â  Mt Algo shelter area is very nice with lots of tenting under pines. Some large branches of green trees came down recently.Â  Too damp for tent to dry out so stayed in shelter.

The plan today was to head into the town of Kent, visit the grocery store and recharge phone at the welcome center. About .8 mile road walk into town was easy in the cool morning.Â  Nothing opened before 8 am so waited around a bit, resupplied at the IGA store.Â  Welcome center rest rooms were still locked at 8:20 am so decided not to wait any longer (later heard they opened not too long aftetwards.) The afternoon surprises were Caleb's Peak and the St Johns Ledges. The descent from the latter was very steep, over slick boulders and took forever!Â  No alternative route once you're up there.Â  Quite tired and glad to finally make it to the shelter.
After a couple of miles, the trail left the shore of the Housatonic River and climbed back into the mountains.Â  Pleasant enough hiking. Nice beaver dam and pond near end of day.

Packed up wet tent in the morning.Â  Later was able to partially dry it next to the trail when the sun came out. 
Wish I knew the outcome of the deer episode.Â  While leaving Mt Easter a young buck (velvet on his growing antlers) walked up to me and sniffed my hand. Later, 5 young thru hikers passed me - in their midst was the same deer!Â  4th in line. Moving at their speed.Â  They thought it was sick. I'm thinking someone hand raised it, and is used to people feeding it.Â 
Trail today went through portions of Great Falls. Ate at Mountainside Cafe and partially recharged my phone.Â  Lovely hiking near the river.Â  Trail went close to the Great Falls which were impressive due to rain (hydro electric plant near by).Â  The trail to the Limestone Spring Shelter was as long and steep as advertised.Â  A good location for scouts or other groups, a poor location if you need to get out of bad weather.

Picking up two packages from the Salisbury Post Office.Â  One is food resupply, the other is replacement hiking pants and tee shirt.Â  Plus a waterproof phone case!Â  Gear and clothes are wearing out after 1,000+ miles of hiking.Â 
Staying in town at a small hostel near the Post Office. Glad for the break in rain today.

Originally planned for a longer hike today but a combination of forecasted rain and widely spaced shelters had me stopping early.Â  Was I antsy about stopping early? You bet.Â  Hard to stop when the weather is still nice.Â Brassie Brook shelter is in a lovely location - partly sunny tree cover,Â  high enough above the brook to be safe from flooding but close enough for convenient access.Â  Picnic table and bear box also. Thunderstorms held off until evening.Â  Several other hikers arrived later in the day.Â  This is the last shelter in Connecticut - tomorrow into Massachusetts.

Wow, this was an incredibly beautiful and very difficult stretch of trail due to wet conditions.. Took 9 hours to hike the 10.6miles.Â  An experienced section hiker hiked with me today and we provided mental support to each other!
Started off at 6 am in fog and very wet conditions.Â  No views all day.Â  By passed Bear Mountain with its rock scramble, took Undermountain Trail, then Paradise Lane Trail which rejoined the AT (1.7 miles longer). The Sages Ravine creek was gorgeous and roaring. Trail followed the creek downstream for a while, then crossed it. No bridge!Â  It really did look impossible to cross safely.Â  In my first attempt I immediately slipped on a rock and sat down right next to the creek bank. Lost a pole but Sage pinned it down before it floated off too far.Â  Water temperature was lovely!Â  I've also double plastic bagged the inside of my pack so not worried about contents getting wet.Â  Only worried about injury or drowning! Looked for a better crossing (none). Then a southbound hiker, Geo, appeared and made it easily across the creek.Â  He graciously offered to help us across.Â  He advised me to face upstream and move feet and poles side to side, holding my arm in case I needed steadying. Amazing the difference body position made!Â  From impossible to do-able!Â  Then Geo helped Sage across.Â  Thank you, Geo!
Two mountains remained to be crossed today. Mt Race and Mt Everett.Â  Steep, rocky ascents and descents. Trail all day was very wet (underwater, even) and muddy.Â  Have never seen it like this before. Gave up on dry feet. Still no views due to clouds.Â  Rock ledges off Mt Race gave me weak knees even without a view.Â  Several groups hiking through area.Â 
Glad to arrive at Glen Brook Shelter. Another beautiful location.

Heading to Rte 7 and Great Barrington for a break.Â  Hike today continued through wet and deeply muddy conditions.Â  No good views again due to morning fog. After descending the ridge, trail was relatively flat but gained hoards of mosquitoes..Â  Sheffield trail angels were offering trail magic under their tarp pavilion.Â  Had a hot dog, watermelon slices and homemade ginger cookies.Â  Wonderful!Â  Later Cosmo, a local trail maintainer,Â  gave us a ride into town.Â  Housatonic River here is flooding.Â  He recommended a short detour when we leave town on Wednesday. Expects trail to be temporarily closed along the river.

Had a lovely breakfast at the Fuel on Main Street.Â  Then resupplied snacks and breakfast bars at CVS next door to Days Inn where I'm staying.Â  Grocery store is not too far but I tend to buy too much that's really too heavy.Â  Thinking it's five days for me to get to Dalton, MA and the next resupply.Â  Expect trail to be muddy and wet tomorrow.Â  Shuttle pick up here at 7 am.

Shuttle driver dropped 3 of us off at the Kellogg Road detour as the Housitonic River was flooding the adjacent trail for the first mile or so.Â  Trail today was very wet and muddy. Rain overnight didn't help.Â  Some nice views although still hazy.Â  The highlight of the day was arriving at Benedict Pond in the Beartown State Forest.Â  To our surprise the park was nearly empty.Â  Closed for camping in 2021 said the website due to Covid-19. Huh?Â  Too late to go elsewhere, we pitched our tents at dusk near the Pond and hung our bear bags.Â  Lovely view of Benedict Pond, although a bit chilly with the wind coming off the water.Â  Full moon and Canadian smoke obscured the night sky.Â  Still wanting a view of the Milky Way!Â  Thanks, Sage, for the wonderful idea to visit this park.
Destination: Benedict Pond, Beartown State Forest, MA

Journal Story: Trail gets marginally drier every day without rain.Â  That is, until we reached the closed section near Tyringham, MA. Still flooded.Â  Before starting the road walk detour, stopped at a delightful refreshment stand for hikers, on the honor system.Â  Some soda, ice pops, recharge phone and water at a picnic table in the shade! The road walk gave us a glimpse of historic Tyringham which was a Shaker Village in the late 1700s. Unfortunately I was getting rather tired and limping so more than ready to trade hard asphalt for the woods trail again.Â  Unable to go further we stealth camped that evening.Â  Left no trace!Â Â Btw, think we did closer to 12 miles, with the extra walk to the trail from the Pond and the extra distance of the roadwalk.
Start location: Benedict Pond, Beartown State Forest, MA
Destination: Stealth camp mile 1544 north of Tyringham, MA

Journal Story: Short hike to Upper Goose Pond Cabin.Â  Sage and I were the first hikers there and thus secured 2 of the 4 available inside bunks.Â  Volunteer caretakers rotate weekly.Â  The short rustic cabin is within view of the pond.Â  Did not go canoeing though others did.Â  Air was wonderful so chilled out in a rocking chair most of the afternoon.Â  Made arrangements for next town stay and read Kindle books.Â  Cool at night. Comfortable mattresses.Â  Blueberry pancakes and coffee (donation based) in the morning.Â  Perfect!
Start location: Stealth camp mile 1544 north of Tyringham, MA

Journal Story:
Sage finished her section hike and has left for home.Â  Best wishes!Â 
Trail not bad today. Mud is drying up with fewer bad, wet sections. Of course it's supposed to rain tonight!Â Â 
A southbound hiker yesterday strongly recommended stopping at the Blueberry Hill by the A.T. ( aka the Cookie Lady). They offered wonderful hospitality to hikers, even though they had a family gathering/picnic in progress.Â  The converted bus was available for the night so I secured it with a donation.Â  Cookies and hibiscus tea.Â  And plates of delicious left overs from the picnic.Â  Phone and power pack are recharged.Â  Life is good.

Rained overnight as forecasted.Â  Waited until rain let up before leaving (about 6:40 am.) Trail not too muddy and wet, yet.Â  After 2 hours of good hiking weather, the next round of rain moved in and drenched everything.Â  After 11 am the rain stopped.Â  Trail horrible on some stretches with slippery mud.Â  Cooked lunch at Kay Wood shelter.Â  Very nice, 2 story design. Too chilly to stay there.Â  Went 3 more miles to Dalton, MA to Tom Levardi's to ask permission to tent in his backyard.Â  Storms passed through about 7:30 pm.

Rained heavily last night for about an hour, then remained foggy until 8 am or so.Â  Decided to wait in Dalton until my tent dried out.Â  Enjoyed sitting on Tom's front porch, drinking coffee and watching the birds at his bird feeders.Â  Went down to Cumberland Farms gas station/convenience store to resupply snacks for a couple of days.Â  By 9 am was on trail. Very late for me!Â  Nice trail to Cheshire. Some mud as expected.Â  Unexpectedly the views were extremely hazy - the smoke from Canadian wildfires presumably.Â  Ate lunch outside at a sandwich shop in Cheshire, chatting with visiting bicyclists (lovely rail to trail path.) Father Tom's campsite is new.Â  Grassy area, porta potty, charging outlets, several bikes to borrow, picnic tablesÂ  town water, and a bear box.Â  Just about perfect! Many thanks to the town and hiking club for providing this service to thru hikers.
Btw, also went to Dollar General in Cheshire.Â  Prices are so good compared to convenience stores that it's hard not to over buy.

No rain last night but a huge amount of condensation soaked the tent just as thoroughly.Â  Nice walk through Cheshire.Â  The trail today went through lovely spruce/fir woods to the summit of Mt Greylock, the highest peak in Massachusetts.Â  The lodge at the summit is closed today but a number of day visitors and bicyclists were admiring the view (hazy as it was,) and the war memorial.Â  After a brief visit went on down the trail.Â  Was running low on water which also motivating to keep moving.Â  Then thunder in the distance. Made it to the Wilbur Clearing Shelter and refilled water bottles about a half hour before severe thunderstorms hit.

Rained heavily last night and morning fog had set in.Â  No views from Mt Prospect.Â  Trail was not unduly muddy and had good switchbacks down from the ridge. Last mile or so was through flat wetlands, a bit buggy.Â  Only 3 miles total to MA route 2 . Since it was still early in the day, decided to walk the mile or so to the motel.Â  Gorgeous weather - low humidity, cool and a breeze - like being on vacation!Â  Hoping some ice and a day off will help shin splints on left leg improve.Â  Wearing compression socks again until temperatures get too hot.
Destination: Howard Johnson Motor Lodge, Williamstown, MA

Journal Story: Spent the day refining the plan for the next two weeks through Vermont.Â  Generally try to have an idea of daily mileage and where to resupply food, recharge phone, hostels and/or hotels for showers and laundry.Â Rain forecasted for this afternoon and tonight.Â  Looking forward to getting back on the trail tomorrow.Â  Have enjoyed the Massachusette Berkshires, even with all the mud and rain.Â  Now ready to tackle Vermont!
Start location: Howard Johnson Motor Lodge, Williamstown, MA
Destination: Howard Johnson Motor Lodge, Williamstown, MA

Journal Story: Late start (about 7:40 am) leaving the motel due to morning showers, as forecasted. Walked the 1.6 mile or so back to the trail.Â  Did not see the bus service, in fact, not much traffic.Â  Trail zig zagged across a foot bridge over rail road tracks, then up the road before going up someone's driveway before entering the woods again.Â  Creeks and streams are roaring from all the rain.Â  Bidding Massachusetts a fond farewell and saying hello to the combined AT and Long Trail in Southern Vermont.Â  More mud, of course.Â  Couple of sudden rain showers at 3 pm left me drenched. Camped next to a lovely beaver pond.Â  Skies cleared and stars were visible over the pond at night.
Start location: Howard Johnson Motor Lodge, Williamstown, MA

Journal Story: Didn't have a phone signal last night.Â  Forgot that Vermont has spotty service.Â  Weather is cool.Â  Trail is muddy.Â  Some pleasant views from Harmon Hill.

A long day due to terribly wet and muddy trail conditions.Â  Seeing a steady stream of AT southbound hikers and Long Trail hikers.Â  Suddenly shelters are crowded again!Â 
Did see a porcupine climbing a tree by the trail.Â  Noticed it because it was chattering like an angry squirrel!Â  Didn't get a good photo.Â 
Rain held off until about 6 pm.Â  I was in a top bunk. Guthook comment regarding roof leak was accurate. Collected a cup of water in my cooking pot under the dripping leak.

Nice, cool weather overnight again. Glad I have my warm sleeping bag, fleece hoody and bubble jacket to keep warm when needed. Wet socks, boots and pant legs (also muddy) drain body heat quickly whenever you stop hiking.Â  Pushed on to this stealth camp site that was about 2 miles from the summit of Mt Stratton and near a stream. Boy, is it dark at night with no moon!

Nice hike to Mt Stratton observation tower.Â  Perfect weather - clear, cool and sunny.Â  Managed to climb the stairs to the 2nd level, which was terrifying enough for me (fear of heights,).Â  Loved the 360 degree views.Â  Spent time sitting beneath the tower (good phone signal) figuring out where to stay in Manchester Center, VT.Â  A hummingbird (!) paused nearby briefly, then flew on.Â  Down the trail, Stratton Pond was clear blue and beautiful.Â  Remainder of day was a struggle with mud until the nice, graded woods road near Prospect Rock. Then back into the fray until reached the enclosed, cabin-like Spruce Peak Shelter.Â  Â As no rain forecasted, I opted to tent on one of the tent pads (mini decks made of wood boards.)

Birds are no longer reliable alarm clocks! Days are slowly getting shorter.Â  Slept poorly last night due to leg cramps. At least the shin splints issue appears to be resolved (will keep wearing compression socks.) On trail by 6 am to be at parking lot for 8:30 am shuttle pickup.Â  Went first to self service laundromat, then ate brunch at The Works Cafe (fabulous), resupplied at grocery store, Subway sub for dinner, and burger at Depot Street Burgers.Â  I will really miss eating like this once I'm no longer hiking!Â  Back on trail tomorrow.

Shuttle driver was running a little late but on trail about 8:15 am.Â  Steady climb to Bromley Mountain, which is topped by a ski lift.Â  Clouds settled in while I was there so not much of a view. Ski lifts look eerie in the fog.Â  Next climb was Mount Styles, then Peru Peak (all under 3,500 feet.)Â  Tented at Peru Peak Shelter which is near Griffith Pond.Â  I was too tired to go on so set up tent on the sole tent pad near the shelter. It had some rotten and broken boards but my one person tent fit in fine. Shelter and other tenting spots filled up quickly.

Had every intention of hiking further this day but was seduced by the lovely Little Rock Pond scenery into staying.Â  To start the day, the trail climbed over Baker Peak. Later passed by the roaring Big Branch Creek.Â  Weather remained partly sunny and warmer than previous weeks.Â  My energy level had not improved from yesterday, so arriving at Little Rock Pond and the associated Shelter was a welcome sight.Â  Unfortunately the popularity of this location meant lots of families and inexperienced hikers.Â  A loud and angry confrontation between others put a damper on the rest of the evening for the rest of us, even though it was finally resolved.

Unexpected rain showers came through about 6 am, delaying the start of hiking by about 40 minutes.Â  Mud that had â°begun to dry out was wet again.Â  Started off slowly and carefully. Skipped some overlooks as no views due to low clouds. A wonderful rock garden next to the trail made up for the lack of scenic vista's. Bully Brook and the Cascades were roaring, full of water. The hike across Bear Mountain was long but not overly strenuous.Â  Arrived at shelter before the afternoon showers. Later filled up plus some tenters. No mice or porcupine visitors at night.

This section is one of the prettiest stretches on the trail.Â  Clarendon Gorge, Gould Brook and Sargent Brook were gorgeous.Â  Spruce and fir forests were great to walk through - muffled by deep duff.Â  Sometimes the trail ran high above the water on a bluffÂ  before dropping back down to cross it.Â  Ended the day at Governor Clement shelter.Â  500 miles remainin!Hummingbirds were visiting the orange flowered jewel weed.Â  Raspberries were still blooming. Rain showers arrived about mid afternoon.Â  Shelter filled up soon after.

Love hiking the Killington section of the trail.Â  Lovely spruce and fir forest gives way to open groves of white birch.Â  Fast hike down the mountain.Â  Decided to resupply and stay overnight in Rutland.Â  Instead of waiting for the next bus,Â  rode to the end of Killington route back to Rutland. Nice!

Really enjoyed my overnight stay at the Yellow Deli Hiker Hostel in Rutland. After breakfast, exited through the back stairs/door which takes you directly to the Bus Transit Station. Caught the 8:15 a.m. bus with about 15 other hikers going to the AT trailhead on rte 4. Most were southbound.Â  Passed the Maine Junction where the Long Trail and AT trails diverge.Â  No more Long Trail hikers!Â  Enjoyed seeing Gifford State Park again.Â  The bathrooms, water and picnic tables are available for use by hikers.Â  Trail skirted around Kent Pond.Â  Long climbs and descents seem to be par for the course in Vermont.Â  Legs and hips are feeling the new challenge!Â  Stayed in the shelter due to forecasted rain which did not materialize.Â  Two other NOBOs, 1 SOBO, and 2 section hikers were there.

Heat advisory in effect until Friday.Â  Taking it slow with frequent rest stops.Â  Loving the white birch and spruce/fir forests.Â  Lots of scenic brooks and creeks.Â  While not too many steep places, there was one ladder descent first thing in the morning. As it was securely bolted to the boulder, it looked harder than it was.Â  Stopped fairly early in afternoon at the shelter.Â  Tented. Hot and buggy. Brief shower overnight.Â  Mostly SOBOs at shelter.Â  I was too tired to say much. Love hearing about NH and the Whites!

The heat wave continued, making frequent stops to cool down a necessity for me.Â  So a long day passed in a blur.Â  Trail crossed several roads and creeks with hills in between.Â  At least it was easy to gauge progress!Â  Great views of the Vermont hills at times.Â  Arrived at Thistle Hill Shelter and was ready to crash.Â  Â Plenty of tent spots.Â  Mostly south bound hikers with a few NOBOs.Â  A warm evening.Â  Too many trees to see the meteor shower!

Plan is to hike to next shelter - slowly with lots of cool down breaks.Â  Compression knee socks resolved shin splints but are hot hot hot to wear!Â  Temperature in the low 90s.Â  No rain last night but Thistle Hill Shelter area filled up!Â  In contrast I was the only one at the Happy Hill Shelter.Â  Unique design, apparently original predated the AT. Rebuilt since then. Large new privy!Â  Downside - No phone signal and water source was starting to dry up.Â 
Moved tent into shelter at dusk when no one else arrived.Â  Mosquitoes were horrendous! Forecasted rain showers came through overnight/ early morning.

Lovely woods today except for voracious mosquitoes.Â  Passed several day hikers heading south. Trail went through part of Norwich, VT, a scenic small town with many historic homes and churches.Â  The road walk to Norwich then Hanover tired me out.Â  My gimpy left leg starts limping on hard surfaces.Â  Took a photo of Vermont New Hampshire state line on the bridge crossing the Connecticut River.Â  Enjoyed the walk in Hanover.Â  Main Street full of parents and college age kids.Â  Stopped at library to recharge phone. Then to Food Co op and to campsite at the edge of town next to AT trailhead.

Taking a rest day in Hanovet, NH.Â  Revised plan for next week to get to next mail drop by next Friday.Â  Elevation maps imply very steep and long ascents and descents.Â  So resting hips and legs today.Â  Back to library when it opens to recharge phone again!

Felt refreshed and energetic after taking a zero day.Â  Trail had its moments but for the most part was not too strenuous.Â  Foggy start to the morning so no view at Velvet Rocks.Â  Too early in the day to stop at Moose Mountain Shelter (yes, I missed seeing the disco ball hung in the privy.) So went on to the Trapper John Shelter. (On the way,Â  some nice views of NH mountains from the Ledges..) Tired at that point so pitched tent, ate dinner and fell asleep early.

As expected, not quite as energetic feeling as yesterday.Â  Rain in forecast so set off for Hexacuba Shelter. Smarts Mountain was a wonderful (not!), steep, never ending climb with some great views.Â  Some alluring tenting spots near the summit. Took a break next to the fire tower but decided not to climb up for a better view (that fear of heights thing.)
The uniquely shaped shelter (six sided) is perched on the side of a mountain.Â  A work crew was building a new privy.Â  A steep walk to water if you didn't bring enough with you.Â  About 7 or 8 hikers in the shelter that night.Â  Rained off and on.

Left shelter at first light as needed to get water (.3 mile) first thing.Â  Mt Cube summit was fogged in but did get some views on the way up.Â  Descent was rather long and slow.Â  At the first road crossing (about 4.5 miles) the hostel was offering sodas and slack packing (I chose to borrow a daypack) the rest of the way to the hostel that evening. My first slack packing experience on the trail!Â  Could get used to it!Â  Made it to the hostel by late afternoon.

Rainy day coincided with planned zero day.Â  Two packages to be picked up at the tiny Glencliff Post Office.Â  Turns out the PO is just across the street from the hostel bunkhouse.Â  Rested and relaxed.Â  New boots will take a few days to break in.Â  Loved the prior pair but the rocks finally wore them out.

Maybe it was the build up of hype over the weeks, but for some reason I was very anxious about my ability to hike the Whites.Â  Today I laid those fears to rest.Â  Well, sort of.Â  Slack packed Mt Moosilauke from Kinsman Notch south to the AT crossing hwy 25 in Glencliff, NH.Â  Weather was foggy and damp but not raining this morning.Â  Very steep climb next to the Cascades was challenging but very doable with a light day pack.Â  Summit was a bit foggy at first and quite windy.Â  Some views of surrounding mountains.Â  Lots of day hikers!Â  Descent was a fairly easy grade most of the way.Â  Several nice streams flowing well.Â  Good hiking today with Bulldog, a thru hiker from TN; not many put up with my slow pace. Back at hostel by 3 p.m. for shower and laundry.Â  Storm Henri is now forecasted to mess up many hikers' plans over the next several days. Looking forward to seeing some family tomorrow as another zero day is planned.

Taking a day off to meet up briefly with family members passing through the area.Â  I'm watching the forecast for Henri updates.Â  Looks like it will be a rain event here vs a wind event.Â  As the trail going forward is exposed and steep in many places, have decided to stay here until Henri passes by.Â  Â Not happy to lose more days of hiking, though.Â  Will put me behind schedule for sure.

SO good to see some family yesterday. Hoping everyone arrived safely at their destinations.Â  Watching Henri storm track predictions.Â  Won't hurt this older hiker to stay put until the storm has passed (although it's very frustrating!)Â  If enough rain, then hiking could be difficult all of next week.

Today Henri was supposed to hit this area.Â  Woke up early to catch the 5 am weather update.Â  Much lower chance of rain. Henri was staying further south.Â  Shuttle back to Kinsman Notch dropped us off about 8:30 am. Some hokers were slackpacking south; I was hiking north with full pack. Steep climb out of Kinsman Notch then a relatively challenging day going over Mt Wolf.Â  Eliza Brook Shelter is very nice and well maintained. Looks new! Two northbound hikers took a break there and left. No one else arrived that evening so had Shelter to myself.Â 
Btw, what is it with these orange colored slugs.. see them everywhere and have accidently squished a few grabbing for handhold on the trail - yuck!

Today's hiking was hard.Â  Started off fine, by the lovely Eliza Brook.Â  Then turned into a steep 2.5 mile climb up rocks and large boulders to get to the South Kinsman summit.Â  Twice, almost couldn't find a way up over large boulders. Adrenaline rush probably helped!Â  A second North Kinsman peak was just as difficult going down. Truly a full body work out, using arms and shoulders to pull up.Â  Scraped palms and a crink in lower back from bending over much of the day.Â  Stopped Lonesome Lake Hut and bought lunch (soup, bread slice, lemonade).Â  Stealth camped that evening about a mile north.
Destination: Stealth camp 1 mile past Lonesome Lake Hut

Journal Story: A straight forward trail today climbed up to Liberty Mtn and then to Franconia Ridge.Â  What a fabulous section of trail on a clear day!Â  Spectacular 360Â  views above treeline.. Had to stop and admire NH:Â  Little Haystack Mtn, Mt Lincoln and Mt Lafayette.Â  Did not visit the Greenleaf Hut as it was a bit far off trail.
Start location: Stealth camp 1 mile past Lonesome Lake Hut

Journal Story: Finished the climb to Mt Garfield early that morning.Â  Summit is capped by a base of an old fire tower.Â  Beautiful view of Franconia Ridge and mountains.Â  By late morning, arrived at Galehead Hut, just behind a group of through hikers.Â  Able to get a plate of left overs to eat.. plus bought couple of brownies for later.Â  Trail then went over Twin Mountain.Â  Considered stopping at Guyot shelter, then realized it was almost a mile from the trail - too far.Â  Â Some thunder in the area and light rain sprinkles so hustled down to Zealand Hut.Â  Quite tired so glad the hut had a bunk available.Â  Felt better after eating dinner at the hut, too.

Trail today was fairly flat, descending toÂ  Crawford Notch, crossing the Saco River, before beginning a steep climb to Webster Mt.(to be tackled tomorrow.)Â  Late start after leisurely breakfast at Hut.Â  Partly sunny, good hiking weather.Â  Visited briefly with Janet, a well known Trail angel with a distinctively decorated van, as I was going towards the hwy at Crawford Notch.Â  Thank you for the soda and orange, Janet!
Destination: Stealth camp past Saco River Trail

Journal Story: Started hiking at 6:30 am in case the weather warmed up.Â  No water for next 6 miles.Â  As expected, it was a steep climb up to Webster Cliffs.Â  Even though the sky was overcast, the views were excellent.Â  Trail climbed another 1.4 miles up some interesting rock scrambles before reaching the summit of Mt Webster.Â  Started to see other hikers about then. After another 1.4 miles with some climbs, arrived at Mt Jackson (a 4,000 footer).Â  Stayed at Mizpah Hut rather than risk no vacancy at Lakes of the Clouds Hut on a Saturday (good decision, as it turned out.)Â  Enjoyed browsing in the hut's library (e.g., which animals leave scat on the trail or on rocks.)Â  Very nice couple from Brooklyn offered to recharge my phone and power bank which both were running low.Â  Thanks so much!
Start location: Stealth camp past Saco River Trail

Journal Story: A bit of a climb and loose, wet rocks didn't help the hike today.Â  Stopping early at Lakes of the Clouds Hut.Â  Very foggy so no views.Â  Didn't see the hut until almost upon it. Very hard to keep motivated in this weather!Â  Watching weather forecast for tomorrow too.

Weather forecast for several hours of rain.Â  Decided to stay put today as my rain gear is useless in these cold and windy conditions.Â  Â Couple of other hikers stayed also.Â  Later heard that a hail storm pummeled hikers near Mt Washington.

Set off after breakfast (just before 8 am). Still fogged in but not drizzling.Â  Wore wool hat and fleece hoodie jacket.Â  Slow hike up the 1.4 miles to Mt Washington was not bad.Â  Fog so thick that I could not see the buildings when I arrived just after 9 am. Snapped a photo of the summit sign, then found the Visitors Center which opened at 9 am. Bought snacks and recharged phone.Â  Only hikers there until the cog trains arrived.Â  Later, gorgeous views after clouds cleared at lower elevations.Â  "Sound of Music" intro played in my head!Â  Wind tunnel effect in a couple of locations made it difficult to hike erect. Glad to see Madison Spring Hut.

Up and over Mt Madison was the most difficult portion of trail to date for me.Â  I didn't understand how the wind would impact hiking conditions.Â  Wore wool hat, fleece hoodie and winter gloves as wind chill would start off in the 20s. Backpack also provides protection.Â  Trail was very rocky so footing was difficult also.Â  While I did make it across the mountain, it took 4 hrs for me to go 3 miles, bent over and holding onto rocks the whole way. Several times wind gusts pinned me down, unable to move, until it let up.Â  Bruised both palms catching myself once.Â  Once back in the treeline, it was a huge relief to be out of the wind. No complaint about the steep, long descent to Pinkham Notch.Â  Joe Dodge Lodge had a few vacancies when I arrived at 3 pm. Bought some resupply at the Visitors Center for the next 3 days.Â  Remnants of storm Ida to pass through tonight and early tomorrow. So glad to get a shower and recharge devices here, too!
Destination: Joe Dodge Lodge at Pinkham Notch

Journal Story: Waited for early morning rain to end, so enjoyed a leisurely breakfast before getting on the trail about 9:50 am.Â  Gorgeous weather for hiking- sunny, breezy and cool. Trail rose steeply from the Notch as they all do.Â  Several very challenging spots for me, but was able to find foot and hand holds to keep moving up and forward.Â  Great views were very motivating.Â  Short mileage for the day was offset by steep climbs in elevation.Â  Very glad to arrive at Carter Notch Hut for the evening.
Start location: Joe Dodge Lodge at Pinkham Notch

Journal Story: Windy and foggy for most of the day.Â  Trail up Carters Dome and over the Carter peaks was not bad.Â  No views on Mt Hight or other peaks.Â  North Carter mtn descent proved quite challenging, mostly to the seat of my pants.Â  Large slabs of rock, aka trail, required what one hiker dubbed "cbs", or controlled butt slide.Â  Later, I slipped twice on wet boards crossing mountain bogs. (And I know how slick they are. ) Even though Imp shelter is .3 mile off the trail it filled up with hikers by dusk.Â  Still very windy.

Full shelter last night. $5 fee collected by caretaker from through hikers. Windy last night.Â  Foggy morning.Â  Some views southwest from ledges on the trail going up Mt Moriah.Â  Clouds back at summit.. strong winds but nothing like Mt Madison experience.Â  Long descent on wet rocks required some caution.Â  Sun appeared by mid morning. Number of day hikers taking advantage of weather and long weekend.Â  Made it to US hwy 2 by 1:30 pm. Hostel is right on trail.
Destination: Rattle River Lodge & Hostel, Gorham, NH

Journal Story: Taking a rest day today.Â  Almost everyone is feeling beat up after the Whites.Â  Shoulders, arms and hands are sore from unaccustomed climbing.Â  Legs and knees ache from steep ascents and descents.Â  Hearing that southern Maine is pretty tough.Â  Ready to get back on trail tomorrow!
Start location: Rattle River Lodge & Hostel, Gorham, NH

Journal Story: Left hostel a bit later than planned, about 6:40 a.m.. Easy to get chatting with other hikers!Â  No waiting for a shuttle when the hostel is right on the trail!Â  Morning started off foggy as usual. Then cleared for some lovely last views of Mew Hampshire.Â  Rained about 2:30 pm for about an hour.Â  The afternoon trail was wet, muddy and slippery.Â  Most of us slipped and fell at least once. Gentian Pond Shelter is the last shelter in NH. It was full when I arrived late in the day so tented on a tent pad.Â  Don't have the special stakes for wooden board tent pads but made due. No rain that night.

Woo hoo - arrived at the NH - Maine state border about mid day.Â  Maine promptly decided to show hikers that it is a tough state too. Mt Carlo and the Goose Eye peaks are under 4,000 ft elevation but boulder climbs late in the day are always hard.Â  One scary descent overÂ  a boulder seemed impossible.Â  GuthookÂ  comment from hikers said to drop pack to do it.. so carefully lowered pack as far as I could, then watched it bound down the trail until stopped by another rock.Â  My "sacrificial" pack cover kept items in outside pockets from falling out, such as my water bottles.Â  I heard a young woman's voice yell from down trail "You can do it!", gathered my courage and butt slid (uncontrolled and blindly) over a drop until one foot touched the next rock.Â  While my risk tolerance has increased, never want to do that again!Â  Â Arrived at shelter late in the day (great group of hikers there) and set up tent on a nearby tent pad.Â  Nice temperatures overnight in 50's and clear sky with stars made for an excellent night. What a long day..

Mahoosuc Notch is known as the hardest mile on the AT.Â  It sure was not what I'd call hiking.Â  I'd say that .1 mile of anything can be fun.Â  Lost it's luster pretty quickly for me.Â  Thought it would take me 3 hrs.Â  Took me 4 hrs.Â  And only 4 because 2 hikers, Rock and Roots, helped get my pack through 3 of the later passageways (I got through the first 3 okay on my own.)Â  Thank you so much!Â  Did not find the Arm ascent to be too difficult as the rock climb up the Arm was mostly dry, even with the 1,500 ft climb in under a mile.Â  Speck Pond was lovely. Stayed in shelter as overnight rain forecasted.

I'm getting mentally accustomed to Maine climbing and hiking but body isn't up to speed yet.Â  Have to say that the views from the summits and ridges are outstanding.Â  Getting there and back is still challenging, especially after rain.Â  It did rain last night.Â  A south bound hiker advised that she mostly remembers Maine as being wet. Hmm...
A number of hikers went into town at Grafton Notch but I have enough food to wait to resupply in Andover, ME.Â  Surprised then to find another group of hikers already at the shelter.Â  Groups are frog hopping past each other based on town visits and the shrinking schedule for reaching Baxter State Park.
Stayed at the shelter. Rained hard overnight.Â  Didn't sleep much, worried when the rain would stop.Â  Have reservation at The Cabin hostel tomorrow night.

Rained stopped before dawn.Â  On trail by 6:40 am.Â  As expected, steep climbs and descents to Baldpate Peaks (East peak was the worst.)Â  Dense fog, strong wind and gusts, and slippery wet rocks seemed worse than usual.Â  With fogged up, wet glasses I can't always find the easiest route up (can't see.)Â  I suspect that contributed to the amount of crawling on hands and knees going up and butt sliding going down.Â  Also boots don't seem to have as much traction as trail runners do.Â  Needless to say, I did make it over and down to Fry Notch Lean-to for a quick lunch break. (Albeit with a new collection of scrapes and bruises, especially on hands and knees.)Â  Afternoon was a wonderful surprise of "normal" trail and fall hiking to East B Hill Road where a shuttle took me to The Cabin hostel.Â Â 
Btw, spotty phone service makes it challenging to make reservations and arrange for shuttles. Dunn Falls did have a signal and I called from there for pick-up as instructed by the hostel.
Destination: The Cabin hostel, East Andover, Maine

Journal Story:
Lovely day today in Maine. Perfect for resting!Â  Maybe hands can start to heal from cuts and swelling. (can't keep bandaids on when gripping wet hiking poles and rocks.) Will get a ride to a local store later. Just need a few days of resupply (until next stop in Rangely, Me.) A few easier sections of trail would be nice too.
Btw,Â  this male spruce grouse was in full display a couple of days ago.Â  Have seen another male and a hen with nearly grown chicks.Â  They were all near the alpine spruce bogs (which are awful to hike through - slippery boards and or treacherous mud holes )
Start location: The Cabin hostel, East Andover, Maine
Destination: The Cabin hostel, East Andover, Maine

Journal Story: Shuttle dropped me back at East B Hill Road.Â  A nice hike, trail a bit less strenuous.Â  Full pack after resupply in Andover.Â  Passed lovely Surplus Pond, then ascended Wyman Mtn.Â  Not ready to stop at Hall Mtn Lean-to.Â  Stealth camped at old shelter location at Sawyer Notch and Brook. A lone picnic table near suitable tent sites was very welcome.Â  A few hikers passed, but I was the only one tenting near this peaceful brook and woods.
Start location: The Cabin hostel, East Andover, Maine

Journal Story: The day started with the steep climb up Moody Mountain, then descended back to South Arm Road and Black Brook.Â  Blue Mountain followed, a long, never ending climb ending on rocky ledges with fabulous views of surrounding mountains.Â  Stealth camped at the intersection with the Bemis Stream Trail (the old AT route). Carried extra water as there is no stream at the intersection.Â  Later two other tenters joined the stealth camp.

Great hiking today.Â  Trail traversed both peaks of Bemis Mtn and the Bemis Mtn Lean-to.Â  Soils are rather thin over solid rock so trees are stunted and widely spaced.Â  Lichens of all sorts and mosses cover much of the ground.Â  Fabulous views today.Â  Later in day, trail climbed steeply to hwy Maine 17 (road to Oquossoc, Maine.)Â  A nice bench at the road provides great view of the lake Mooselookmeguntic and mountains. Trees are beginning to turn fall colors.Â  An easier trail led to Sabbath Day Shelter, near Sabbath Day Pond.Â  Rain forecasted overnight and tomorrow.

Rain held off overnight and thunderstorms now forecasted for the afternoon. Trail much easier than expected with only a few minor steep spots.Â  Reserved room and arranged for shuttle when signal was available.Â  Discovered last night that the power bank had failed after recharging phone to 80%.Â  Need to visit outfitter too as sleeping mattress is now deflating (think it's the valve, not a hole.) Also cheap poncho is shredding and needs replacement.Â  Need fuel canister (small) and pack chest clip replacement (cracked.)Â  Also grocery store for resupply until next stop in Stratton.

Arranged for an 8:30am shuttle back to the trail.Â  Not going far.Â  Only to Eddy Pond to enjoy the beautiful weather and Maine woods.Â  Pack is heavy with resupply so eating is also part of the plan.Â  Two other hikers also tented here later in the day.Â  No moose.Â  ATVs used the nearby gravel road but did not stay.

While I expected the hike over the Saddlebacks to be hard,Â  the beauty of the scenery and excellent weather made for fabulous hiking.Â  Most of this section is above the tree line.Â  High level clouds from last night's rain were racing away.Â  Only 2 day hikers appeared as I neared the summit of Saddleback Mtn.Â  The steep downhills required some climbing over boulders.Â  The 360 degree views from the "Horn" were even more spectacular.Â  Did well keeping my boots dry until the Oberton Stream crossing.Â  I was a bit too tired to make a leap to the second boulder. Slid off (did not fall) and just waded across. Water less than shin deep.Â  Too late in the day for socks and pants to dry.Â  Changed into dry clothes after setting up tent.Â  One other hiker tenting nearby.

Journal Story: Lone Mountain was the main climb on this section of the trail.Â  Otherwise the morning section of the trail was very nice.Â  Fall colors are becoming more noticeable. A steep, 1 mile long boulder field descent was almost too much at the end of a long day.Â  As a rain storm had just passed over,Â  the trail was wet.

Journal Story: The climb over the 2 Crocker Mount as in peaks was over soon.Â  Fairly easy, downhill sloping trail for rest of the day.

After a fabulous breakfast at the hostel, took my time getting packed up and caught a 9:30 am shuttle to the trail.Â  Planned an easy 5 mile day that would position me to climb the Bigalows the next day.Â  Chatted along the way with a couple of weekend hikers who were preparing for a hike in Canada.Â  Lovely fall weather.Â  At Horns Pond Lean-to,Â  tented at the first dirt tent pad. Several other thru hikers arrived later. No moose.Â  Lovely full moon.

What a day!Â  The Bigalows are the last 4k mountains before reaching Katahdin.Â  The Horn was a nice warm up climb. Wind was strong going up the first peak but nothing I hadn't dealt with before.Â  Still, it rather ruins the moment as one is not able to peacefully savor the summit.Â  The wind moderated somewhat by the second peak. Fabulous views. Turns out Little Bigalow was challenging too.Â  Great views there too. Makes a huge difference to hiking when the rocks are dry!Â  Much easier! Arrived at shelter late in day.

Heard that this section of trail was flatter and easier.Â  So it was.Â  The trail wound past the huge and gorgeous Flagstaff Lake (I had not heard of it before.)Â  Round Mountain was not difficult.Â  Made it to the shelter by 1:30 pm or so.Â  Rain forecasted arrived shortly after so glad I stayed at the shelter.Â  West Carry Pond was visible through the trees and a short walk from the shelter.Â  No moose. Did see the huge wasp nest over trail, now detoured around it.

Trail today followed a portion of the route that Benedict Arnold and small army took in 1775 in an attempt to surprise the British in Quebec.Â  Can't imagine the effort to portage their boats between the ponds!Â  West Carry Pond and East Carry Pond are directly next to the trail. Some sketchy board "bridges" were helpful but nerve wracking.Â  Made good time and arrived at Pierce Pond Lean-to in early afternoon.Â  Tented as I heard a large group of thru hikers were on the way (10-13.)Â  Just as well as stomach troubles hit just after arriving.Â  I've learned to leave my backup light (Petzl) on in the tent so I can find the tent easier after a night time walk to the privy.Â  Â Light rain and mist most of the night.

Overnight rain and mist left everything wet.Â  Trail rocky and rooty in places.Â  Took it slow to not slip.Â  Arrived at Kennebec Ferry (aka canoe) at 9 am.Â  Greg and his golden retriever Maggie were very pleasant and patient with us hikers.Â  Ferried 2 hikers at a time.Â  Short walk to Post Office in the tiny town of Caratunk.Â  Was going to wait there until it opened at 2 pm. Then decided to call for the shuttle to Sterling Inn (not far but far enough if walking.) With heavy rain forecasted, arranged to stay at the Inn.Â  Received mail drop packages, including replacement power bank for recharging phone on trail.Â  Staying in bunk room.Â  Not sure about plans for tomorrow.Â  Depends on weather.

Really enjoyed the overnight stay at the historic Sterling Inn.Â  After breakfast, caught an 8:30 am shuttle back to the trail.Â  Heavy rain all day yesterday, now foggy morning.Â  Easy hiking.Â  A short day planned. Suspect I've contracted Giardia, so not feeling great.Â  My bad for not replacing my failing (abused?) water filter earlier.Â  Or not being careful enough when getting water from ponds?Â  Stopped early at shelter as more rain is forecasted even though the afternoon turned partly sunny.Â  Sure enough,Â  heavy rain started after midnight.Â  Two other hikers at shelter and a couple others tenting.Â  Could hear some locals partying down at the Pond after dark.

Raining heavily still at 5 am so didn't start packing until it started to ease up an hour or so later. Rain jacket useful for trip to privy!Â  On trail about 7:20 am.Â  Pleasant Mountain was the only real ascent for the day.Â  Had phone signal at peak.Â  Later in the day, several hikers were watching and filming a bald eagle fishing at Moxie Pond.Â  The water ford at Bakers Creek was fine (no wet feet.) Not true at Bald Mountain Creek right before the side trail to the shelter.Â  Lovely, roaring creek was maybe 8 feet across but no way to cross without getting ones feet wet. Current strong enough to require caution.Â  Forgot how unpleasant and cold wet boots and socks can be!Â  Only 1 southbound hiker at shelter area that night.Â  He advised that the upcoming West Branch and East Branch of the Piscataquis River were too high to cross safely.Â  Recommended calling for a shuttle around these.Â  Frankly, didn't realize how much rain this area had gotten!Â  Guide book warns against crossing during high water but doesn't offer any alternatives.

Chilly morning (44 degrees). Trail still very wet from all the rainfall.Â  Took the bad weather bypass around Bald Mountain summit.Â  Just couldn't face more rock climbs today.Â  Some great views anyway! When rejoined the trail, had a phone signal.Â  Arranged for shuttle pickup about midday with Shaw's Hiker Hostel.Â  Planning to stay there and mail drops are at the Monson Post Office.Â  The hostel is very busy with lots of hikers!Â  Seeing some familiar faces which is great!Â  Some were able to get through the high water fords. Others are skipping flooded sections or waiting for the waters to go down.

Taking a rest day today and tomorrow.Â  Picking up mail drops at Post Office later this morning.Â  Will arrange for food drop half way through the upcoming 100 mile wilderness (a bit pricey but totally worth it.)Â  Saw more familiar faces at breakfast today.Â  Loved catching up with other hikers.Â  Some are further along the trail but had returned to the hostel to give water a chance to recede.Â  Multiple water crossings ahead!

Last night, made reservations at Baxter State Park for Katahdin Stream campsite for 2 days (night before and day of summit.)Â  Today will finish preparing food drop for Jo-Mary Road about 60 miles from here.Â  Then will finalize reservation for shuttles and lodging the day after finishing Katahdin.Â  Planning to take 10 days to finish the 100 mile wilderness.Â  Food drop will include 3 extra days of food since Abol Store will be closed when I get there.Â  Looking forward to a break from planning!

After breakfast, took a shuttle to next town of Greenville for medical appointment then to pharmacy to fill prescription.Â  After 7 days what a relief to get rid of (presumed) Giardia!Â Â Dropped off at trailhead on Maine hwy 6.Â  Short hike to Leeman Shelter.Â  The fall foliage is now in full color!Â  Rain threatened but only slight drizzle, then stopped.

What a day for water crossings!Â  Took off boots and socks for 3 of them and waded across barefoot.Â  As hoped for, the water levels had gone down over the past several days.Â  None were particularly difficult.Â  Two were almost knee deep.Â  The widest, Big Wilson, had a guide rope, but was not needed.Â  Decided to stealth camp and hold off crossing Long Pond Stream in the morning.Â  Heard that it was still higher than I like to cross.

Journal Story:
The day ended well, with a lovely campsite at the remote mountain Cloud Pond.Â  Still no moose sightings, though.
Early in the day, the Long Pond Stream crossing was as challenging as I expected. Any more so and I would not have attempted it.Â  Another hiker had sent me a text with a suggested crossing upstream after bushwhacking 200 yards.Â  I was wading barefoot (feet are numb from the cold water) and thought I was at the spot.Â  Turns out that I wasn't, but did make it across.Â  One deep hole wet my pants up to the crotch.Â  Current was strong but manageable.Â  Finally, almost on shore when I slipped on the smooth rock bank and fell forward on hands and knees in relatively shallow water.Â  Unfortunately my boots, tied together and hanging from my hip belt,Â  did dip into the water and get soaked, as did the wool hiking socks stuffed in them. (Not sure why I thought that was a good idea.)Â  Takes days for the boots and socks to dry when there's no sun.Â  Other hikers didn't seem to have the same difficulty so I'm sure I just don't have enough experience yet to pick out a good route.
Start location: Stealth camp at old logging road before Long Pond sfeam

Journal Story: Trail today went over 3 of the 4 peaks on Chairback Mountain, named Fourth Mountain, Third Mountain and Columbus Mountain.Â  Â Fewer hikers on the trail.Â  A couple of climbs but nothing too strenuous. Hiker hunger had returned with a vengeance after being suppressed while ill. Didn't pack enough food for these first 6.5 days.Â  (Food drop pickup in 4 days.)Â  Fall foliage continues to amaze.Â  Also saw pitcher plants while crossing the Fourth Mountain bog.

Gorgeous fall weather. Leaves are entering peak season for color.Â  Chairback Mountain was not too strenuous. Trail went over four peaks today: Gulf Hagas mtn, West Peak, Hay mtn and White Gap mtn.Â  Beautiful weather again!Â  Tons of moose signs. Kudos to the trail maintainers!Â  White pine woods are silent, bright green moss on woods floor and boulders.Â  Noisy red squirrels send the alarm when hikers pass by.

Very clear skies.Â  Perfect blue as was the pond.Â  Hiking through red and gold carpets of leaves. Too cold for me to swim in the large pool in front of the shelter but other hikers took a dip!Â  Have I mentioned the robins passing through in small groups?Â  Seems late for migration south.

Amazing!Â  Â Rest of the day was a lovely hike.Â  Fabulous weather continues. Red squirrels are everywhere, busy hoarding food for the coming winter.

Day started off with a climb up Nesuntabunt Mountain.Â  Not very tall but did give a nice view of Katahdin in the distance over Nahmakanta Lake.Â  Did stop an take in a few views later, including Pollywog Gorge, highlighted by gorgeous sugar and red maples in full color.Â  Fairly easy trail helped me make good time to the next Lean-to site.Â  Excellent weather continues.Â  Loons serenaded at night from Rainbow Lake.

Nostalgic already for the 100 Mile Wilderness.Â  Trail went went and over the Rainbow Ledges where fires many years ago burned away the soil and vegetation.Â  Good views. Fast and easy hike today.Â  A bit confusing to start as white blazes not visible due to some road work in progress.Â  Once at Baxter trail entrance, the ranger working there *trail name Log Jam, made sure I knew the registration process for the AT pass and camping.Â  As I'd already reserved 2 nights at Katahdin Stream campground, I would not need to register for the Birches tenting area.Â  Didn't realize that Baxter has no showers or potable water (use the stream and treat your water.)Â  So while very beautiful and nice camping sites, not sure I'd go camping there if not hiking. Ready to finish this long "covid interrupted thru hike."

On trail at 6:40 am.Â  By staying 2 nights I was able to leave my tent and most gear at the camp site, taking only what is needed for a day hike.Â  The first mile is easy and fast.Â  The next 4.2 miles to Baxter Peak involve 4,000 ft climb over mostly exposed terrain. Several other hikers also finished yesterday.Â  Good weather will hold another couple of days.Â  How perfect!Â  Tomorrow will take the bus to Bangor, then later a flight to Jacksonville.Â  Ready toÂ  get home!
